news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/fears-of-a-nofun-olympics-in-beijing-20080718-3hkb.html |title=Fears of a 'no-fun' Olympics in Beijing |date=19 July 2008 |work=The Age |accessdate=9 August 2008 |first=Mary-Anne |last=Toy |location=Melbourne, Australia |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140316015953/http://www.theage.com.au/world/fears-of-a-nofun-olympics-in-beijing-20080718-3hkb.html |archivedate=16 March 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]]'''s Liam Fitzpatrick stated that the report by the ''SCMP'' was "unconfirmed", and its information was from "anonymous" sources.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://time-blog.com/china_blog/2008/07/one_world_one_dream_one_seriou.html|title=One World, One Dream, One Serious Allegation|work=Time|date= 18 July 2008|accessdate=10 August 2008}}</ref> Equally, ''The Washington Post'' interviewed several black bar patrons in Sanlitun, all of whom said they had not been denied service.<ref name=africans/> China's official news agency [[Xinhua]] stated on 21 July the alleged "bar policy" was groundless and the city's public security departments, including Sanlitun police, never demanded any bar not serve customers from any region or country ahead of the games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/07/22/asia/AS-OLY-China-Bar-Ban-Denial.php|title=China denies report of ban on Africans, Mongolians in bars for Olympics|work=International Herald Tribune|date= 22 July 2008|accessdate=10 August 2008}}</ref>
==== Professionalism and etiquette ==== The Beijing government issued new mandates requiring police officers in the city to act more professionally, warning that violators would be reprimanded. By doing this, Beijing hoped to clean up its image in time for the games. The government circulated pamphlets urging officers to desist from using foul language, being arrogant, and hanging up on people who call to report crimes.<ref name="Police conduct">{{cite news |publisher=[[GamesBids]] |url=http://www.gamesbids.com/cgi-bin/news/viewnews.cgi?category=1&id=1178899588 |date=11 May 2007 |title=New Guidelines For Beijing Police Ahead of 2008 Games}}</ref>
A drive was also launched to improve [[Engrish|incorrect English translations]] common on Chinese signage and labelling in readiness for the Olympics.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/6052800.stm |title=Beijing stamps out poor English| publisher=BBC News |date= 15 October 2006}}</ref> Signs were placed around Beijing, instructing locals not to ask any non-Chinese personal questions for fear of causing discomfort to tourists and athletes.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nbcolympics.com/wgal/news/newsid=154888.html |title=Etiquette guide: What not to ask Olympic visitors |publisher=NBCOlympics.com |date= 23 July 2008}}</ref>
=== Opening ceremony === {{Main article|2008 Summer Olympics opening ceremony}}
====Participant exclusion==== Hong Kong [[Bishop (Catholicism)|Bishop]] [[John Tong Hon]] said of his acceptance to participate in the opening ceremony that “while the leaders of the six largest religions in Hong Kong were invited to Beijing, only in the case of the Catholic Church was an invitation not sent to the highest authority. I am embarrassed because our government ignored [[Joseph Zen Ze-kiun|Cardinal Zen]] and invited me instead.” He expressed his desire that China's government would someday give “the same importance to greater religious and social freedom that it had in cleaning up Beijing's pollution in anticipation of the games,” nonetheless noting that “the Olympic Games [still showed] the progress of China”.<ref name="cna">{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/new.php?n=13474|title=Chinese bishop explains reasons for participating in Olympic opening ceremonies|agency=Catholic News Agency|accessdate=10 August 2008|date=8 August 2008}}</ref><ref name="standard">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking_news_detail.asp?id=2176|title=China snubs Zen, invites deputy|work=The Standard|accessdate=10 August 2008|date=8 August 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522085905/http://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking_news_detail.asp?id=2176|archive-date=22 May 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="cns">{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0804042.htm|title=Hong Kong bishop says he has mixed feelings about attending Olympics|publisher=Catholic News Service|accessdate=11 August 2008|date=7 August 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080813011739/http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0804042.htm|archive-date=13 August 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="ucaninv">{{cite web|url=http://www.ucanews.com/2008/06/13/bishops-from-hong-kong-macau-invited-to-beijing-olympics-opening/|title=Bishops From Hong Kong, Macau Invited To Beijing Olympics' Opening|date=13 June 2008|work=Union of Catholic Asian News|accessdate=11 August 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080615163424/http://www.ucanews.com/2008/06/13/bishops-from-hong-kong-macau-invited-to-beijing-olympics-opening/|archive-date=15 June 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====Singing==== [[Ode to the Motherland]], sometimes called "the second national anthem" of the PRC, was lipsynched by Lin Miaoke. The song actually broadcast was a recording of another girl, Yang Peiyi. Chen Qigang, the ceremony's chief musical director, claimed that this was because a senior [[Politburo of the Communist Party of China|Politburo]] member had commented that Lin's singing was not good enough, but preferred Lin's appearance to that of Yang.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/13/sports/olympics/13beijing.html?ex=1376280000&en=925892efa500e4d3&ei=5124&partner=permalink&exprod=permalink | work=The New York Times | title=In Grand Olympic Show, Some Sleight of Voice | first=Jim | last=Yardley | date=13 August 2008 | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/olympics/2545387/Beijing-Olympics-Faking-scandal-over-girl-who-sang-in-opening-ceremony.html| title=Beijing Olympics Faking scandal over girl who sang in opening ceremony|work=The Daily Telegraph |date=12 August 2008 | location=London | first=Richard | last=Spencer | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7556058.stm| title=China Olympic ceremony star mimed| publisher=BBC|date=12 August 2008 | first=Michael | last=Bristow}}</ref> Sun Weide, the spokesman for the Beijing organising committee, said however that the decision to use both girls was made by the artistic director after consulting with broadcasters, who had recommended the change.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/08/13/asia/AS-OLY-China-Lip-Synched-Song.php |title=Chinese defend Olympic ceremony lip-synch |agency=Associated Press |work=International Herald Tribune |date=13 August 2008}}</ref>
====Firework display==== [[File:2008 Summer Olympics Opening Ceremony 2.jpg|190px|right|thumb|[[Beijing National Stadium]] during the opening ceremony]] One part of the fireworks show, which displayed the 29 footprints that wandered into the Bird's Nest from outside the stadium, was simulated by computer animation to portray the real fireworks due to the hazy smog conditions and safety concerns with flying a helicopter near the display.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=93522548 |title=Live From Beijing: Computer-Enhanced Fireworks |publisher=NPR |accessdate=9 November 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/olympics/2534499/Beijing-Olympic-2008-opening-ceremony-giant-firework-footprints-faked.html| title=Beijing Olympic 2008 opening ceremony giant firework footprints 'faked'| work=The Telegraph|date=10 August 2008 | location=London | first=Richard | last=Spencer | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/TECH/08/12/fake.fireworks.ap/ |title=Beijing enhanced Olympic show with faked 'fireworks' |publisher=CNN |date=12 August 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905161152/http://www.cnn.com/2008/TECH/08/12/fake.fireworks.ap/ |archivedate=5 September 2008 }}</ref>
== Participants' issues == A number of sportsmen were criticised for their behaviour at the games: *The [[China national under-23 football team|Chinese men's football team]] was severely criticised by the domestic media for its poor sportsmanship, particularly during the match against [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgium]]. Defender [[Tan Wangsong]] was red-carded for kicking Belgium's [[Sebastien Pocognoli]] in the lower abdomen, while [[Zheng Zhi]] was ejected for elbowing an opponent.<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref>{{cite news | title=Belgium beats nine-man China 2–0 at Olympic soccer match |date=10 August 2008 |work=China Daily | url =http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/olympics/2008-08/10/content_6922502_2.htm |agency=Xinhua News Agency }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Belgium beat nine-man China 2–0 at Olympic soccer match |date=10 August 2008 | publisher=[[Chinaview]] | url =http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-08/10/content_9147022.htm |agency=Xinhua News Agency | accessdate = 30 August 2008 }}</ref> *[[Mohammad Alirezaei]] of [[Iran]] was to race against [[Israel]]'s [[Tom Be'eri]] in the fourth heat of the [[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's 100 metre breaststroke|100 meter breaststroke]], but pulled out, allegedly under the orders from officials of the Iranian delegation for [[Iran–Israel relations|political reasons]].<ref>{{cite news | first=Allon | last=Sinai | title=Iranian refuses to race Israeli swimmer in Beijing | date=11 August 2008 | url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1218104248620 | work=The Jerusalem Post | accessdate=30 August 2008 }}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=IOC comments on Iran-Israel swimming controversy | date=10 August 2008 | publisher=[[Anchorage Daily News]] | url=http://www.adn.com/24hour/olympics/story/489923.html | work=The Sports Network | access-date=30 August 2008 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080818144245/http://www.adn.com/24hour/olympics/story/489923.html | archive-date=18 August 2008 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> *Swedish wrestler [[Ara Abrahamian]] refused his bronze medal in [[Wrestling at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's Greco-Roman 84 kg|84 kg Greco-Roman wrestling]] in protest over the judging of a semifinal match.<ref>{{cite news|title=Angry Swedish wrestler ditches medal |date=16 August 2008 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/olympics/wrestling/story/2008/08/14/olympics-abrahamian-tantrum.html |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819020456/http://www.cbc.ca/olympics/wrestling/story/2008/08/14/olympics-abrahamian-tantrum.html |archivedate=19 August 2008 }}</ref> *Cuban [[taekwondo]] athlete [[Ángel Valodia Matos]] kicked referee [[Chakir Chelbat]] in the mouth, leaving him needing seven stitches for a cut lip, after being ruled to have retired when an injury timeout (Kyeshi) expired.<ref>{{cite news | title=Olympic Buzz: Cuban athlete kicks referee in face |date=23 August 2008 | url =http://www.kansascity.com/sports/olympics/story/763456.html | publisher=[[The Kansas City Star]] | accessdate = 30 August 2008 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Afterwards, Matos punched a judge in the arm and spat on the arena floor before he and his coach, who accused the referee of taking bribes from Kazakhstan officials, were escorted from the arena by security. Matos' results at the Beijing Games were deleted, and the [[World Taekwondo Federation]] banned Matos and his coach from WTF events for life.<ref>{{cite news | first=Lynn | last=Zinser | title=Cuban Athlete Is Barred for Kicking Referee in the Face |date=23 August 2008 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/24/sports/olympics/24kick.html |work=The New York Times | accessdate = 30 August 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Ian | last=Ransom | title=Cuban banned for referee kick | date= 23 August 2008| url =https://www.reuters.com/article/wtMostRead/idUSPEK30514420080823 | agency=Reuters | accessdate = 30 August 2008}}</ref> *Chinese taekwondo judges were accused of throwing a match to a [[Hanna Zajc|weaker opponent]] so that the [[Wu Jingyu|Chinese competitor]] in the next match would win.<ref>{{cite news | first=Dave | last=Feschuk | title=Result questioned by Canadian medal hopeful in taekwondo |date=20 August 2008 | url =http://olympics.thestar.com/2008/article/481950 |work=Toronto Star | accessdate = 30 August 2008 }}</ref>
[[File:Spanish-national-team-chinese-eyes1.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The Spanish basketball team posing with 'slit-eyes']]
=== Advertisement in Spain === Prior to the start of the Games, the Spain Men's and Women's Basketball teams featured in ads that appeared in the Spanish daily sports newspaper ''[[Diario Marca]]''.<ref name="guardian-spain">{{cite news | first=Sid | last=Lowe | title=Olympics: Spain's eye-catching faux pas |date=11 August 2008 | url =https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2008/aug/11/olympicsbasketball.olympics20081 |work=The Guardian | location=London}}</ref> The athletes, dressed in uniform and assembled at a center court bearing a dragon logo, posed with their hands pulling back the skin on their eyes. ''[[The Guardian]]'' said: "No one involved in the advert appears to have considered it inappropriate nor contemplated the manner in which it could be interpreted in China and elsewhere."<ref name="guardian-spain" /> A spokesman for the Organization of Chinese Americans said that the photo was "clearly racist, and not even in a jovial way".<ref>{{cite news | first=David | last=Schoetz | title=Spain's 'Slant-Eye' Team Photo Stirs Ire |date=12 August 2008 | url =http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/story?id=5563668&page=1 | publisher=American Broadcasting Company }}</ref> Point guard [[José Calderón (basketball)|Jose Manuel Calderon]] said the team was responding to a request from the photographer, while teammate [[Pau Gasol]] said it was "absurd" people were calling the gesture racist.<ref>{{cite news |accessdate=23 August 2008|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/26173075/ |date=13 August 2008 |title=Spanish players defend controversial photo}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |work=The New Zealand Herald |accessdate=23 August 2008|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/category/story.cfm?c_id=87&objectid=10527014 |date=14 August 2008 |title=Spanish defend Olympic 'slant-eye' photo }} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/26173075/#.USTwEaCzu0s|title=Spanish players defend controversial photo|year=2013|publisher=Associated Press|website=nbcnews.com|accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref> The IOC said "clearly it was inappropriate, we understand the team has apologised and absolutely meant no offence whatsoever", and considered the matter closed.<ref>{{cite news | title=Spain basketball squad's slit-eyed ad 'inappropriate': IOC | date=13 August 2008 | publisher=[[Google News]] | url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5i0I01CICOLuFtMXFPBfo_G0PcSfA | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121003134708/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5i0I01CICOLuFtMXFPBfo_G0PcSfA | dead-url=yes | archive-date=3 October 2012 | agency=Agence France-Presse }}</ref>
=== FIFA v football clubs dispute === In July 2008, the football clubs representing players taking part in the games, [[FC Schalke 04]], [[SV Werder Bremen]] and [[FC Barcelona]], made an appeal to the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] to prevent their star players, namely [[Brazil national under-23 football team|Brazil's]] [[Rafinha (footballer, born 1985)|Rafinha]] and [[Diego Ribas da Cunha|Diego]] and [[Argentina national under-23 football team|Argentina's]] [[Lionel Messi]] respectively, from playing at the Olympics.<ref name="guardian-football">https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2008/aug/06/olympics2008.olympicsfootball</ref>
FIFA's rule states that it was mandatory to release all players aged 23 or under for the Olympics which was overturned on July 30, 2008, stating that "The Olympic Football Tournament Beijing 2008 is not included in the Co-ordinated Match Calendar and there is no specific decision of the FIFA Executive Committee establishing the obligation for the clubs to release players under 23 for this tournament."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/2510034/Lionel-Messi-out-of-Olympics-after-Barcelona-win-court-appeal-against-Fifa.html|title=Lionel Messi out of Olympics after Barcelona win court appeal against Fifa|date=6 August 2008|website=telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref> This meant clubs were entitled to recall their players from the games if they wished.<ref name="guardian"/>
Despite the ruling, FIFA appealed to the club, Rafinha and Diego was released for the games under the provision that their salaries was paid for by the [[Brazilian Football Confederation]].<ref name="thestar">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/story.aspx/?file=%2f2008%2f8%2f8%2folympics%2f22034795&sec=Olympics|title=Messi allowed to play for Argentina in the Olympics|date=8 August 2008|website=thestar.com.my|accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref> Despite resistance from his employer,<ref name="guardian"/> Messi was eventually released for the games.<ref name="thestar"/>
[https://web.archive.org/web/20140726140504/http://jurisprudence.tas-cas.org/sites/CaseLaw/Shared%20Documents/1622%2C%201623%2C%201624.pdf Full CAS summary]
=== Allegation of underage gymnasts === {{See also|Age requirements in gymnastics}} In early 2008, [[Yang Yun (gymnast)|Yang Yun]], an artistic gymnast who won two bronze medals at the [[2000 Summer Olympics]], admitted on state-run television that she was 14 when she had competed.<!--The admission was made on "Yang Yun:My Olympics" which was released before the Olympics and was confirmed by the media in July 2008.--><ref>[http://www.latimes.com/sports/olympics/la-sp-gymnastics28-2008jul28,0,7119550,full.story "Issues raised about Chinese athletes' ages"] Diane Pucin, ''Los Angeles Times'', 28 July 2008.</ref> Consequently, there was frequent speculation that members of the Chinese women's gymnastics team were 14 years of age or under,<ref name="Macur">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/10/sports/olympics/10age.html?ref=olympics |work=New York Times | accessdate=6 October 2008 | title=Teeny-Tiny Matter of Age for China's Gymnasts | last=Macur | first=Juliet | date=10 August 2008}}</ref> violating the [[Age requirements in gymnastics#Current regulations|minimum age requirements]] of [[International Federation of Gymnastics]] (FIG), the governing body of the sport, that requires gymnasts to be 16. Younger gymnasts are lighter and more supple than adult gymnasts,<ref name="Sydney Herald Controversy"/> and have also been said to be more fearless when performing difficult manoeuvres.<ref name="NYTimes Controversy"/><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/27/sports/olympics/27gymnasts.html |title=Records say Chinese gymnasts may be underage |work=The New York Times | accessdate=13 August 2008 |date=27 July 2008 | last=Longman | first=Jeré | last2=Macur | first2=Juliet}}</ref>
[[File:Jiang Yuyuan.jpg|thumb|140px|left|[[Jiang Yuyuan]], one of the gymnasts investigated for, and later cleared of, [[Age requirements in gymnastics#Age falsification|age falsification]]]] The New York Times claimed that official media and some official Web sites in China, including that of the State General Administration of Sport, listed Chinese gymnasts' details which indicated that [[He Kexin]], [[Jiang Yuyuan]] and [[Yang Yilin]] may have been as young as 14.<ref name=error>{{cite news | first=Juliet | last=Macur | title=China Cites Paperwork Error in Age of Gymnast |date=24 August 2008 |work=The New York Times | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/25/sports/olympics/25games.html | accessdate = 31 August 2008 }}</ref> During the Olympics, media focused their attention on [[He Kexin|He]], [[Yang Yilin|Yang]], [[Jiang Yuyuan|Jiang]], and [[Deng Linlin|Deng]].<ref name="Macur"/> In response, Chinese officials claimed the discrepancies for He Kexin were caused by paperwork errors when the gymnast switched teams.<ref name=error/> Chinese authorities presented passport information to show that they were 16 years old as of 2008.<ref>{{cite news | author=Ann Killion | title=Chinese gymnasts too young to know any better? |date=13 August 2008 | url =http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_10185795 |work=San Jose Mercury News | accessdate = 31 August 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Most Memorable Moments of the 2008 Beijing Olympics |date=26 August 2008 |url=http://www.asianweek.com/2008/08/26/asianweek%E2%80%99s-most-memorable-moments-of-the-2008-beijing-olympics/ |work=AsianWeek |accessdate=31 August 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827213328/http://www.asianweek.com/2008/08/26/asianweek%E2%80%99s-most-memorable-moments-of-the-2008-beijing-olympics/ |archivedate=27 August 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> Chinese coach Lu Shanzhen explained that Chinese competitors had for years all been small. "It is not just this time. It is a question of race. European and American athletes are all powerful, very robust. But Chinese athletes... are by nature that small."<ref>{{cite news | title=IOC: No proof China cheated in gymnastics |date=22 August 2008 | url =http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/26337759 | publisher=[[MSNBC]] | accessdate = 16 September 2008}}</ref> Sportswriter E.M. Swift criticised the IOC for "spend[ing] millions of dollars trying to ferret out drug cheats [while ignoring] allegations of institutionalized cheating" by the Chinese government.<ref>{{cite news|title= The IOC's handling of the underage gymnast controversy is a shame |url= http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2008/olympics/2008/writers/em_swift/08/20/underage.opinion/ |author=E. M. Swift |work=Sports Illustrated |date= 20 August 2008}}</ref>
On 22 August 2008 the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) instructed the FIG to investigate the allegations that He Kexin was under-age,<ref name="Sydney Herald Controversy">{{cite news|last=Hutcheon|first=Stephen |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/off-the-field/ioc-calls-for-probe-into-china-star/2008/08/22/1219262483864.html |title=IOC calls for investigation into gymnast's age |work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=22 August 2008 |accessdate=22 August 2008}}</ref> and were asked to report back to the IOC later that day.<ref name="NYTimes Controversy">{{cite news|last=Macur|first=Juliet|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/22/sports/olympics/22age.html?_r=1&hp&oref=slogin |title=I.O.C. Asks for Inquiry of Chinese Gymnasts |work=The New York Times |date=22 August 2008 |accessdate=22 August 2008}}</ref> The FIG accepted passport ages as valid proof and declared gymnasts eligible.<ref name="NYTimes Controversy"/> On 23 August, further pressure led the FIG to request additional documentation on five of the six athletes on the Chinese team.<ref name=request>{{cite web |url=http://209.20.80.25/vsite/vcontent/content/news/0,10869,5195-191062-208285-45462-288924-news-item,00.html |title=Artistic : Age of gymnasts |publisher=International Gymnastics Federation official announcement |date=23 August 2008 |accessdate=27 August 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829034201/http://209.20.80.25/vsite/vcontent/content/news/0%2C10869%2C5195-191062-208285-45462-288924-news-item%2C00.html |archivedate=29 August 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> IOC president [[Jacques Rogge]] said that FIG had demanded "birth certificates and all the documents like [[Hukou system|family books]], entries in schools and things like that." While the FIG investigation was in progress, the IOC indicated reshuffling of the medals was unlikely.<ref>{{cite news | title=Rogge says gymnasts' paperwork appears to support China claims |date=24 August 2008 | publisher=[[ESPN]] | url =http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/summer08/news/story?id=3551294 | agency=Associated Press | accessdate = 31 August 2008 }}</ref> Having been satisfied with the proof of age received from the Chinese Gymnastics Association, the FIG ended the investigation on 1 October 2008, concluding that He and her teammates were eligible to compete.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.iht.com/articles/reuters/2008/10/02/sports/OUKSP-UK-GYMNASTICS-CHINA.php |work=International Herald Tribune |date=2 October 2008 | accessdate=6 October 2008 | title=Officials say Chinese Olympic gymnasts not underage}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/02/sports/olympics/02gymnastics.html?scp=1&sq=Ruling%20Backs%20Chinese%20Gymnasts&st=cse |title=Ruling Backs Chinese Gymnasts |agency=Associated Press |work=The New York Times|date=1 October 2008|accessdate=1 October 2008 | first=Juliet | last=Macur}}</ref>
[[File:Osaka07 D7A Xiang Liu celebrating.jpg|170px|right|thumb|Many Chinese attributed [[Liu Xiang (hurdler)|Liu Xiang]]'s injury and withdrawal from the [[Athletics at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's 110 metres hurdles|110 meter hurdles]] to excessive pressure he faced]]
In a related story, Yang's teammate in 2000, [[Dong Fangxiao]], was subsequently revealed to have lied about her age. She claimed to have been 17 in 2000, but worked as a technical official at the 2008 Games, and her certification gave a birthdate of 1986—which would have made her 14 years old in 2000. In 2010, the FIG erased Dong's scores, and the IOC stripped China of its team bronze for 2000.<ref name="MSN Foxsports">{{cite web|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/olympics/story/IOC-strips-China-of-bronze-medal-24803166?Gt1=39002|title=No kidding: China stripped of gymnastics medal|publisher=[[Fox Sports Net]]|date=28 April 2010|accessdate=28 April 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100502005202/http://msn.foxsports.com/olympics/story/IOC-strips-China-of-bronze-medal-24803166?Gt1=39002|archive-date=2 May 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== State training and expectations of Chinese athletes === As the host country, China's very high expectations put immense pressure upon athletes and coaches alike. [[Liu Xiang (hurdler)|Liu Xiang]], the defending Olympic champion for the 110 meter hurdles, had pulled out of the heats with an injury.<ref name="liu pressure"/> His victory in Athens four years ago was China's first gold medal in track and field, regarded by some as dispelling the widespread view that Chinese physiology was unsuitable for such a discipline. Hyped by the state and sponsors, with his fame and endorsements exceeding that of [[Yao Ming]] in China, Liu's withdrawal disappointed millions with some accusing him of being afraid to lose,<ref>{{cite news | title=China's Liu Xiang pulls out of 110 meter hurdles | url=http://www.cbc.ca/olympics/athletics/story/2008/08/18/olympics-athletics-liu.html | publisher=[[CBC.ca|Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] | date=18 August 2008 | accessdate=17 October 2008 | quote='I think he may have wanted to win too much and could have caved under the pressure,' said a suspicious He Shen. 'The injury may be an excuse.'| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080822064253/http://www.cbc.ca/olympics/athletics/story/2008/08/18/olympics-athletics-liu.html| archivedate = 22 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://features.csmonitor.com/olympics08/2008/08/18/the-agony/ |title=The agony: Chinese hurdler Liu Xiang drops out of race |work=The Christian Science Monitor |date=18 August 2008 |accessdate=9 November 2009}}</ref> while others suggested that excessive pressure may have worn him out.<ref name="liu pressure">{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/heartbreak-for-china-as-hero-limps-out-before-first-hurdle-901853.html | title=Heartbreak for China as hero limps out before first hurdle | date=19 August 2008 | accessdate=17 October 2008 | last=Coonan | first=Clifford |work=The Independent | quote=The national pressure crushed him. After the Athens Olympics, Chinese people concentrated on him very much. (...) I think the pressure from 1.3 billion Chinese people is too much for a man. Just let him have a good rest. | location=London}}</ref> Liu's coach had been told by government officials that "if Liu could not win a gold medal in Beijing, all of his previous achievements would become meaningless."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.sportingo.com/olympic-games/a10002_did-weight-chinese-expectation-prove-too-much-liu-xiang|title=Did the weight of Chinese expectation prove too much for Liu Xiang? |author=Craig Hackney |date=18 August 2008}}</ref> [[Josef Capousek]], a former rowing coach, was fired by China's sporting federation over a contract dispute. He had argued in favour of the objective declared in the German version, to "aim" to get a gold medal, and against the Chinese-language version which stated that his athletes "must" win the gold medal. He said "nobody can guarantee a gold in any sport...but here, anything less than gold means nothing."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/sports/ci_10136505 |title= For Chinese athletes, huge expectations |author=Mark Purdy |work=Mercury News |date=8 August 2008}}</ref>
There has also been criticism of the Chinese government's training regime. Parents and children endure considerable personal sacrifices – young children often leave their families to endure long and tough training regimens in the state academies, where 250,000 children are enrolled.<ref name=sacrifice>{{cite news |url = http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/08/05/sports/gymnast.php |title=Chinese gymnast endured childhood sacrifice |work=International Herald Tribune|author=David Barboza |date=5 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/20/world/asia/20olympics.html |title=In Quest for Gold and Glory at Olympics, China Pressures Injured Athletes |work=The New York Times |author=Howard W. French| date=20 June 2008}}</ref> Critics also say that the sports schools focus on training at the expense of general education, leaving athletes unprepared to leave the sports system that has raised them. [[Yang Wenjun]], a C-2 Canoeing champion at the Athens Olympics, told ''[[The New York Times]]'' that he was ill-equipped to go to college or start a business. He recounted officials' threats to withhold his retirement income if he quit before the Beijing Games, adding that it was "not possible to survive without those benefits". While Yang and his family have received numerous rewards for his achievement (including white collar jobs, stipends, performance bonuses, endorsements, and an apartment), he has not seen his parents in three years.<ref name=medalfactory>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/21/sports/olympics/21athlete.html |title= In China's Medal Factory, Winners Cannot Quit |author=Juliet Macur |work=The New York Times |date=21 June 2008}}</ref>
On the opposite side, for those athletes who do win Gold medals, the State offers a significant performance bonus. [[Cheng Fei]], for example, could look forward to more than $150,000 in cash and bonuses for every Olympic Gold Medal she wins.<ref name=sacrifice/> Yang said his wins at the [[2002 Asian Games]] netted him about [US]$28,600 in bonuses –more than the money his parents can earn in ten years.<ref name=medalfactory/>
=== Doping === {{Main article|Doping at the Olympic Games#2008 Beijing}}
Out of 4,500 samples that were collected from participating athletes at the games, six athletes with positive specimens were ousted from the competition. Although the rate of positive findings was lower than at the [[2004 Summer Olympics]], doping experts expressed concern due to advances in doping technology.<ref name="dwde">{{cite web| url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,3530852,00.html |publisher=Deutsche Welle |title=Beijing Faces Big Challenge in Keeping Olympics Drug-Free|date=3 August 2008 }}</ref><ref name="spiegel082308">{{cite journal |url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/sonst/0,1518,573934,00.html |author=kna/reuters|title=Ukrainischer Gewichtheber Razoronov positiv getestet |journal=Der Spiegel|date=23 August 2008 }}</ref><ref name="McGrath" /> In July 2008, a [[BBC]] investigation reported that samples positive for [[erythropoietin]] were labelled as negative by [[World Anti-Doping Agency|WADA]]-approved laboratories.<ref name="McGrath">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/7516484.stm |author=Matt McGrath |publisher=BBC |title=Concerns over Olympic drug test |date=21 July 2008}}</ref> The IOC stated in October 2008 that it would begin retesting samples for [[Continuous erythropoietin receptor activator|CERA]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-10/10/content_10173506.htm|title=IOC to retest Beijing doping samples|date=10 October 2008|agency=Xinhua News Agency}}</ref>
In April 2017, the Olympics has had the most (49 of 50) [[List of stripped Olympic medals|Olympic medals stripped]] for doping violations. Russia is the leading country with 14 medals stripped off.
== Political issues leading up to the games ==
=== Migrant workers === The [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) estimated that China had 150 million migrant workers out of a total national working population of 764 million people at the end of 2006. More than 40 million of these migrant workers were employed in construction, an industry in which some 90 percent of the workforce was composed of migrants.<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/reports/2008/china0308/china0308webwcover.pdf China “One Year of My Blood”] Exploitation of Migrant Construction Workers in Beijing REPORT March 2008</ref> [[2008 Summer Olympics]] [[migrant workers]] routinely endured dangerous work environments and lacked any safety net, including medical and accident insurance. Problems of [[migrant workers]] included unpaid wages and high legal costs.<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/reports/2008/china0308/ "One Year of My Blood" Exploitation of Migrant Construction Workers in Beijing] [[Human Rights Watch]] summary</ref>
=== Boycotts === [[File:Steven Spielberg by Gage Skidmore.jpg|150px|left|thumb| American film director [[Steven Spielberg]]'s decision not to help direct the opening ceremony drew worldwide attention]]
Calls for sustained pressure and boycotts of the Olympics came from former French presidential candidate [[François Bayrou]],<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L22161580.htm | title = Call for Olympic boycott stirs up pre-poll France| date = 22 March 2007 | first = Kerstin | last = Gehmlich | publisher=AlertNet | agency=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> Sudan scholar Eric Reeves<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article20210 | first = Eric | last = Reeves | title = On Darfur, China and the 2008 Olympic Games | publisher=[[Sudan Tribune]] | date = 11 February 2007 | accessdate = 28 March 2007}}</ref> and the editorial board of ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/13/AR2006121302008.html | title = China and Darfur: The Genocide Olympics? |work=The Washington Post | accessdate = 9 August 2008 | date=14 December 2006}}</ref> In February 2008, American film director [[Steven Spielberg]] announced he was stepping down from his role as an artistic advisor in protest of the Chinese government's refusal to pressure [[Sudan]] to stop the "continuing human suffering" in the Darfur region, urging it to do more to stop "these crimes against humanity."<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7242016.stm |publisher=BBC| title= Spielberg in Darfur snub to China|date= 13 February 2008}}</ref> European Parliament Vice-President [[Edward McMillan-Scott]], called for a boycott of the Beijing games; and praised the [[Prince of Wales]] for not attending the Games.<ref>{{cite news|title=Steven Spielberg pulls out of Beijing Olympics role over crimes against humanity in Sudan|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-514012/Steven-Spielberg-pulls-Beijing-Olympics-role-crimes-humanity-Sudan.html#ixzz24s5tOTLj|accessdate=11 February 2013|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=13 February 2008|location=London}}</ref> Additionally, 106 lawmakers in the United States circulated a letter calling for the US to boycott the Olympics because of China's support of the Sudanese regime<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/SP319572.htm |title=China defends Darfur role, deflects Olympic warning| agency=Reuters |date=10 May 2007}}</ref> and the forced relocation of 300,000 poor Chinese<ref name="300k evicted" /> to make room for the games. US Senators [[John McCain]] and [[Barack Obama]] both claimed that they would have boycotted the ceremony if they were in the White House.<ref>{{cite news|last=Walt|first=Vivienne|title=Why Nobody's Boycotting Beijing|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1823561,00.html|publisher=Time Inc.|accessdate=12 February 2013|date=16 July 2008}}</ref> Polish prime minister [[Donald Tusk]], became the first EU head of government to announce a boycott and was soon joined by President [[Václav Klaus]] of the Czech Republic. The German chancellor, [[Angela Merkel]], said she will not attend opening of the Beijing Olympics.<ref>{{cite news|title=Merkel says she will not attend opening of Beijing Olympics|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/29/germany.olympicgames2008|accessdate=11 February 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=29 March 2008|location=London|first1=Ian|last1=Traynor|first2=Jonathan|last2=Watts}}</ref> The Geneva-based group [[Centre on Housing Rights and Evictions]] claimed that 1.5 million Beijing residents would be displaced from their homes for the construction of Olympics venues. Beijing's Olympic organising committee and China's [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Foreign Ministry]] stated that 15,000 residents from 6,037 households were displaced.<ref>{{cite news | author=Nick Mulvenney | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idUSPEK36399820080219 | title = Beijing says 15,000 relocated for Games venues | date = 19 February 2008 | agency=Reuters | accessdate = 9 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/19/AR2008021901612.html|title=China Defends Relocation Policy|first=Maureen|last=Fan|work=The Washington Post |date=20 February 2008 |accessdate=9 August 2008|author2=Jie, Zhang}}</ref> Some sources said that as of May 2005, 300,000 residents were evicted in preparation for the games and that police in Beijing placed many people under arrest for protesting against the evictions.<ref name="300k evicted">{{cite news | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/article526586.ece | title = Thousands of homes destroyed to make way for Olympic tourists |work=The Times | date = 26 May 2005 | author=Jane Macartney | accessdate = 14 May 2006 | location=London}}</ref> Protester Ye Guozhu, who attempted to draw public attention to alleged [[Forced eviction (China)|forced evictions]] in Beijing due to Olympics-related construction, was sentenced in December 2004 to a four-year prison term for "picking quarrels and stirring up trouble".<ref name=mistakes>{{cite web| url= https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/olympics-china-and-ioc-must-learn-mistakes-and-uphold-human-rights-values-200808 |title=Olympics: China and IOC must learn from mistakes and uphold human rights values| publisher=Amnesty International|date= 24 August 2008}}</ref>
The [[British Olympic Association]] (BOA) required that British participants signed an agreement before leaving for China, promising not to comment on any "politically sensitive issues." However, a BOA spokesman stated that the BOA's intention was not to censor athletes, but to reaffirm the IOC charter, which prohibits demonstration of political, religious or racial propaganda in any Olympic venues.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sport.guardian.co.uk/breakingnews/feedstory/0,,-7298200,00.html |work=The Guardian |title=Olympics – UK athletes barred from political comments |date=10 February 2008 |accessdate=10 February 2008 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214074359/http://sport.guardian.co.uk/breakingnews/feedstory/0%2C%2C-7298200%2C00.html |archivedate=14 February 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_122.pdf |title=Olympic Charter |publisher=International Olympic Committee |date=16 October 2007 |accessdate=10 February 2008 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727143137/http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_122.pdf |archivedate=27 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
In general, attendance at the 2008 games was highly politicised, with as many as 80 political heads of state attending;<ref>{{cite web|last=Kosyrev|first=Dmitry |url=http://en.rian.ru/analysis/20080806/115849259.html|title=Beijing Olympics as a diplomatic convention|accessdate=9 August 2008|agency=RIA Novosti|date=6 August 2008 }}</ref> several major political figures, however, considered boycotting the Games for political reasons. On 2 April 2008, the Japanese government announced that its royal family would not participate in the opening ceremony because of the international concern focused on the violent crackdown in Tibet.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sankei.jp.msn.com/politics/policy/080402/plc0804020108000-n1.htm|title=Japanese royal family will not attend opening of Beijing Olympics|accessdate=2 April 2008 |date= 2 April 2008|work=Sankei Shimbun| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080404043434/http://sankei.jp.msn.com/politics/policy/080402/plc0804020108000-n1.htm| archivedate = 4 April 2008}}</ref> On 5 April, the newspaper ''[[Le Monde]]'' reported that [[President of France|French President]] [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] hoped that there would be an end to violence against Tibetans, the release of political prisoners, light to be shed on the events and the opening of dialogue with the [[Dalai Lama]] before the opening ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gbv20Oxll_oabfy9mRNZDU1DPYHg|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080528045116/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gbv20Oxll_oabfy9mRNZDU1DPYHg|dead-url=yes|archive-date=28 May 2008|title=Paris sets conditions for Sarkozy to attend Olympics: report|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Google|date=5 April 2008|accessdate=5 April 2008}}</ref> ''The [[BBC]]'' wrote that while Sarkozy was opposed to a full boycott, he would "not close the door to any possibility" as far as his own attendance was concerned.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7332543.stm|title=Sarkozy aide 'misquoted' on Games|publisher=BBC News|date=5 April 2008 |accessdate=5 April 2008}}</ref>
=== Terrorist incident === {{See also|2008 Xinjiang attack}} On 10 April 2008, China announced that it had foiled a plot against the games by [[East Turkestan independence movement|Uyghur separatists]] in [[Xinjiang]]. According to the Chinese security ministry, separatists planned suicide bomb attacks on Chinese cities and kidnappings in Beijing to disrupt the Olympic Games. Uyghur activists claim that the Chinese fabricated these terror plots to prevent people in the region from voicing their grievances with the Han Chinese.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7340181.stm | title = China 'foils Olympic terror plot' | date =10 April 2008 | accessdate = 9 August 2008 | publisher=BBC }}</ref> On 25 April 2008, [[Interpol]] issued a warning that there was a real possibility that the Beijing Olympics would be targeted by terrorist groups.<ref name="interpol" />
China reported 35 arrests as part of a ten-day raid.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/04/10/olympic.plot/index.html | title = China says 35 arrested in Olympics bomb plot | publisher=CNN | date =10 April 2008 | accessdate = 9 August 2008}}</ref> On 4 August 2008, two attackers detonated [[hand grenades]] at a police post near [[Kashgar]], killing 16 policemen.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7540138.stm | title = Chinese border assault kills 16 |date=4 August 2008 | accessdate = 9 August 2008 | publisher=BBC}}</ref>
=== Tibetan independence groups === {{See also|2008 Tibetan unrest|Tibetan independence movement}} [[File:Free Tibet banner.jpg|thumb|left|150px|The {{convert|140|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} banner which read "ONE WORLD ONE DREAM FREE TIBET"]] [[File:Tibet Olympics.jpg|thumb|150px|Pro-Tibetan independence protests during the [[2008 Summer Olympics torch relay|Olympic Torch Relay]].]]
==== Boycott calls ==== Some [[International Tibet Independence Movement|pro-Tibetan independence]] groups, such as [[Students for a Free Tibet]], initiated a campaign against the Beijing 2008 Summer Olympics<ref>{{cite news | title = Protests, Smog Cloud Olympics a Year Out | agency=Associated Press | first = Stephan | last = Wade |date=7 August 2008}}</ref> to protest for Tibetan independence, It also objected to the use of the [[Tibetan antelope]] (chiru) as the [[Fuwa]] Yingying.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.studentsforafreetibet.org/article.php?list=type&type=15 | title = Free Tibet 2008! – One World, One Dream: Free Tibet 2008 | accessdate = 8 January 2007 | publisher = Students for a Free Tibet | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070101074244/http://www.studentsforafreetibet.org/article.php?list=type&type=15 | archive-date = 1 January 2007 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref> The Tibetan People's Movement has also demanded representation of [[Tibet]] with its own national flag. American film actor [[Richard Gere]], chairman of the [[International Campaign for Tibet]] called for a boycott to put pressure on China to make Tibet independent. There were also plans by Tibetans in exile to hold [[Tibetan Olympics 2008|their own version of the Olympics]] in May, at the headquarters of the exiled government.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.hindustantimes.com/storypage/storypage.aspx?id=f35048f8-e21b-4858-88ad-1956f57372c7&ParentID=d0415f44-d6d6-47c6-b39f-9a84c8322530&MatchID1=4664&TeamID1=5&TeamID2=2&MatchType1=1&SeriesID1=1173&MatchID2=4673&TeamID3=4&TeamID4=8&MatchType2=1&SeriesID2=1177&PrimaryID=4664&Headline=Tibetan+Olympics+from+May+15-25 | title = Tibetan Olympics from 15 May-25 | date = 20 March 2008 | accessdate = 9 August 2008 |work=Hindustan Times |location=India }}</ref>
The international journalist group [[Reporters Without Borders]] (RSF) advocated boycott to express concerns over violations of free speech and human rights in China. It hoped that international pressure could effect the release of [[prisoners of conscience]] and the upholding of [[Beijing 2008 Olympic bid|promises made to the IOC]] regarding improvements in human rights.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rsf.org/rubrique.php3?id_rubrique=174 | title = Repression continues in China, one month before Olympic Games | accessdate = 9 August 2008 | publisher = [[Reporters Without Borders]] | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20020601081212/http://www.rsf.org/rubrique.php3?id_rubrique=174 | archive-date = 1 June 2002 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
In March 2008, Taiwan's president-elect [[Ma Ying-jeou]] threatened a [[Chinese Taipei]] Olympic Committee boycott "if the situation in Tibet continues to worsen".<ref name="ma ying-jeou"/><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.bangkokpost.com/sportsplus/sportsplus.php?id=126577 |title=Olympics 2008: Taiwan presidential candidate threatens to boycott Beijing Olympics| work=Bangkok Post}}</ref> Masahisa Tsujitani, a Japanese craftsman who makes shots used by many Olympic athletes, announced 14 April he refuses to allow his wares to be used at the games to protest China's treatment of protesters in Tibet.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/asection/la-fg-boycott11apr11,1,5033988.story |title=Craftsman's 16-pound Olympic boycott| author=Bruce Wallace |date= 11 April 2008 |page= A-9, |work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
==== Disruption of torch relay ==== {{See also|2008 Summer Olympics torch relay}} During the Olympic torch lighting ceremony in Greece on 24 March 2008, three Reporters Without Borders journalists breached a cordon of 1,000 police at the ancient Olympia stadium and interrupted the speech of Liu Qi, head of the Beijing Games committee.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/03/24/torch.relay/index.html |title=Protests disrupt Olympic torch ceremony |publisher=CNN |date=24 March 2008 |first=Anthee |last=Carassava |accessdate=9 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518194307/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/03/24/torch.relay/index.html |archivedate=18 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> One protestor tried to snatch the microphone as another unrolled a black flag showing the Olympic rings as handcuffs.<ref name="the Sun 25mar08">{{cite news | work=The Sun | title = Tibet's Olympic flame of fury | url = http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/article956407.ece | date = 25 March 2008 | accessdate = 25 March 2008 | author=Lucy Hagan | location=London}}</ref>
Nearly 50 Tibetan exiles in India began a global torch relay 25 March 2008 with a symbolic "Olympic" flame that ended in Tibet on 8 August 2008, the day of the Summer Games' opening ceremonies in Beijing.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/03/25/tibet.protest.relay.ap/index.html | title = Tibetan exiles stage fake Olympic relay | publisher=CNN| date =25 March 2008 | accessdate = 9 August 2008| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080612112230/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/03/25/tibet.protest.relay.ap/index.html| archivedate = 12 June 2008}}</ref> Although the torch was heavily guarded by local police and Chinese security agents wearing blue track suits, protesters attempting to stop the relay or take the torch were a significant problem along the route.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120765486995597695 | title = Torch's Guards Have a Link to Tibet | publisher=wsj.com | date = 9 April 2008}}</ref>
Disruption of the torch relay and foreign condemnation of China resulted in a backlash of [[Chinese nationalism|nationalism]] and anti-foreigner sentiment in China.<ref name=timeburning>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1734821,00.html|title=Why China's Burning Mad|work=Time|date=24 April 2008|accessdate=26 April 2008}}</ref> French goods and businesses were threatened with a reprisals for the assault on torch-bearers through Paris, France. French retailer [[Carrefour]] was boycotted, and there were [[flag desecration|flag burning]] protests outside some stores.<ref name=timeburning/> Foreign media, particularly [[CNN]], was severely criticised for its reporting of the Tibetan riots.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2008-04/02/content_6587120.htm |title=CNN: What's wrong with you? |work=China Daily |date=2 April 2008 }}</ref> The media reported that the attitudes of Han Chinese citizens towards non-Chinese and Chinese minorities in China noticeably worsened. In late April, Chinese Internet censors, who had previously permitted posts critical of non-Chinese, began blocking words such as "Carrefour", in what was seen as an attempt to calm tensions before the games.<ref>{{cite news |title=Carrefour Removed From Chinese Internet 30 April 2008 |publisher=China Tech News |url=http://www.chinatechnews.com/2008/04/30/6693-carrefour-removed-from-chinese-internet/}} </ref>
== Human rights and censorship == {{See also|Human rights in China|Censorship in China|Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China|Golden Shield Project}}
=== Protest permits and zones === [[Liu Shaowu]] announced on 23 July that the [[Public Security Bureau]] would issue permits for protesting in [[protest zone]]s during the Olympics.<ref>{{cite news | title=Beijing allows protests but you need a permit | date=24 July 2008 | publisher=China Internet Information Center | url =http://www.china.org.cn/2008-07/24/content_16059733.htm | work=Shanghai Daily | accessdate = 17 August 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Protest application procedure piles out |date=4 August 2008 | publisher=China Internet Information Center | url =http://www.china.org.cn/china/national/2008-08/04/content_16126025.htm | work=China Daily | accessdate = 17 August 2008 }}</ref> The three designated locations were [[Purple Bamboo Park]], [[Temple of the Sun]], and [[Beijing World Park]].<ref>{{cite news | first=Paul | last=Eckert | title=Protesters bypass China's official protest zones |date=6 August 2008 | url =https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSSP5422420080806 | agency=Reuters | accessdate = 17 August 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=John | last=Garnaut | title=Arrest threat means protest park is for the birds |date=15 August 2008 | url =http://www.theage.com.au/world/arrest-threat-means-protest-park-is-for-the-birds-20080814-3vpa.html |work=The Age | accessdate = 17 August 2008 | location=Melbourne, Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=China sets a Catch-22 for would-be dissenters |date=12 August 2008 | work=[[The Baltimore Sun]] | url =http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/world/bal-te.protests12aug12,0,5980032.story | accessdate = 17 August 2008 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> On 18 August it was reported that of 77 applications, 74 were withdrawn, two suspended and one vetoed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7567703.stm|title=China 'yet to approve protests'|last=Bristow |first=Michael|date=18 August 2008 |publisher=BBC News|accessdate=22 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/O/OLY_CHINA_PROTESTS?SITE=SCCOL&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |title= China has not approved Olympic protest requests |author=Audra Ang |agency=Associated Press | date= 18 August 2008 |accessdate= 19 August 2008}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
A number of protest applicants claim that they were wrongfully discouraged, rejected, or denied permits altogether.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2008094518_chinaprotest06.html|title=Great stonewall of China: Protest permits denied|date=7 August 2008 |accessdate=16 August 2008|author=Ariana Eunjung Cha|work=The Seattle Times}}</ref><ref name="torontostar">{{cite news | first=Bill | last=Schiller | title=Silence reigns in protest park |date=15 August 2008 | url =http://olympics.thestar.com/2008/article/478962 | work=Toronto Star | accessdate = 16 August 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Nicholas | last=Kristoff | title=Malcontents Need Not Apply |date=16 August 2008 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/17/opinion/17kristof.html | work=The New York Times | accessdate = 17 August 2008 }}</ref> Some who applied for permits went missing or were detained.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Jill Drew |author2=Ariana Eunjung Cha | title=No Permits, No Protests in Beijing's Special 'Pens' |date=15 August 2008 |work=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/14/AR2008081403420.html?hpid=topnews | accessdate = 16 August 2008 }}</ref> Others say they have decided against applying because they feared that the process was a means to collect information about dissenters.<ref name=wouldbe>{{cite news | author=Ariana Eunjung Cha | title=China's Would-Be Protesters Denied |date=6 August 2008 |work=The Washington Post | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/05/AR2008080503197.html?hpid=topnews | accessdate = 17 August 2008 }}</ref>
*A Beijing woman was denied a permit to protest the razing of her home for Olympic-related development, she and 20 supporters protested one day before the Olympics.<ref name="torontostar" /> Her son claims that she was then jailed for "disturbing social order".<ref>{{cite news | first=Aileen | last=McCabe | title=Games a chance for China to let guard down | date=16 August 2008 | work=Ottawa Citizen | url=http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/story.html?id=19d96354-ba1b-4291-b8af-dd79521b6997 | publisher=Canwest News Service | accessdate=16 August 2008 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625152639/http://www2.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/story.html?id=19d96354-ba1b-4291-b8af-dd79521b6997 | archive-date=25 June 2009 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> *A representative of 140 property owners in [[Suzhou Industrial Park]], who sought to protest unjust behaviour by Suzhou officials in a land dispute, was interviewed by a PSB official, and then sent her back to Suzhou by four Suzhou officials who placed her under house arrest.<ref name=wouldbe/><ref>{{cite news | author=Josephine Ma | title=Protest-zone test case blocked in Beijing | date=2 August 2008 | url=http://olympics.scmp.com/Article.aspx?id=1856&section=insight | work=South China Morning Post | accessdate=17 August 2008 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014222741/http://olympics.scmp.com/Article.aspx?id=1856&section=insight | archive-date=14 October 2008 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Andrew | last=Jacobs | title=Beijing's protest zones: Apply at your own risk |date=13 August 2008 | url =http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/08/13/asia/protest.php | work=International Herald Tribune | accessdate = 16 August 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Rowan | last=Callick | title=Olympic 'protest pens' empty |date=12 August 2008 | url =http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/beijing_olympics/story/0,27313,24166771-5014104,00.html |work=The Australian | accessdate = 17 August 2008 }}</ref> *Two elderly women from Beijing, aged 77 and 79, who applied five times to protest during the Olympics against what they believed was inadequate compensation for the demolition of their homes in Beijing in 2001,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/20/AR2008082001095.html?hpid=topnews?hpid=topnews |work=The Washington Post|date= 20 August 2008|title=Protest Application Brings Labor-Camp Threat, Woman Says|author=Ariana Eunjung Cha|page= A10}}</ref><!-- Broken link, ref not necessary<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5i3OMvEA_ehIHkQwvUsKHCWZ5QzIAD92M97LG2 |agency=Associated Press |title=4 more foreign activists detained in China |author=Audra Ang |date=20 August 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080823224131/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5i3OMvEA_ehIHkQwvUsKHCWZ5QzIAD92M97LG2 |archivedate=23 August 2008 }}</ref>--> received a suspended one-year non-judicial sentence of [[re-education through labour]] for "disturbing the public order".<ref name=Elderly>{{cite news|title= Elderly pair punished for wanting to protest|author=Peter Simpson |pages= A5|work=South China Morning Post|date= 21 August 2008}}</ref> *An entrepreneur from [[Hunan]] province disappeared after trying to file for a permit to demand greater participation of citizens in political processes, and denounce rampant official corruption and abuses of power. His friend, a legal advocate from [[Fujian]], stepped in to apply for protest permits and was reportedly escorted from the building and put into an unmarked [[Buick]] by several men, and also disappeared.<ref name="voices.washingtonpost.com"/><ref>{{cite news | title=Police Detain Would-Be Olympic Protesters |date=13 August 2008 | publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] | url =http://hrw.org/english/docs/2008/08/12/china19601_txt.htm | accessdate = 16 August 2008 }}</ref> *According to ''The New York Times'', a farmer from [[Heilongjiang]] mailed an application to protest in early August. When he went to Beijing to follow up a week later, he was promptly escorted back to Heilongjiang by authorities, and was being held by police near [[Xingyi, Guizhou|Xingyi]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/14/sports/olympics/14protest.html?adxnnl=1&ref=sports&adxnnlx=1220069571-aW5u1tdeaPM0rFe58U39fQ |work=The New York Times|date= 13 August 2008|title=Specter of Arrest Deters Demonstrators in China|author= Andrew Jacobs}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/19/sports/olympics/19protest.html |work=The New York Times|date= 18 August 2008|title=Would-Be Protesters Detained in China|author=Andrew Jacobs}}</ref>
=== Web and media censorship === China pledged in its [[Beijing 2008 Olympic bid|Olympic bid]] that it would allow open media access during the games, but [[Human Rights Watch]] alleges that it had failed to do so.<ref name=twoconcerns>{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/09/sports/olympics/09beijing.html?ref=olympics |title=Two Concerns for Olympics – Air and Access |work=The New York Times |date= 9 July 2008 | first=Jim | last=Yardley | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref> While some estimated 20,000 journalists had been assured unfettered Internet access by the IOC's [[Jacques Rogge]], Sun Weide (孙伟德) of the Beijing Organizing Committee announced in late July that China would allow only "convenient" access – still blocking sites which reference controversial content.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/548f4410-5e3a-11dd-b354-000077b07658.html |title= China limits Olympics journalists’ web access|author=Mure Dickie |work=Financial Times |date= 30 July 2008}}</ref> The IOC and broadcasters were uncertain as to whether the Beijing authorities would allow them to broadcast live from locations such as [[Tiananmen Square]], fearing protests. In 2001, Beijing announced there would be complete freedom for the media to report in China. After lengthy discussions, broadcasters were permitted to broadcast between the hours of 6–10 am and 9–11 pm with prior permission; however, live interviews were banned at all times.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/latest-news/global-anger-at-internet-blockade/2008/07/31/1217097434368.html?page=2 |title=Global anger at internet blockade|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=1 August 2008}}</ref> Many broadcasters were unhappy with this decision as it would "set a bad precedent in regards to [[press freedom]]", and were pushing the authorities further on the issue.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5jZQlFFurD2ZlbELDE_X1jGKo12vwD91T1AS00 |title=Broadcast access to Tiananmen remains at issue |agency=Associated Press |date=13 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080802215837/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5jZQlFFurD2ZlbELDE_X1jGKo12vwD91T1AS00 |archivedate=2 August 2008 }}</ref>
In late July, US senator [[Sam Brownback]] alleged that foreign-owned hotels in China were ordered by the government to install equipment to monitor internet use by guests. Foreign Ministry spokesman Qin Gang said that the security arrangements did not exceed "what is normal internationally".<ref name=spyon>{{cite web|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gAkDaSkHWHboscdhQZwdRBt6hZnw |agency=Agence France-Presse |publisher=Google |title=China plans to spy on Olympic hotel guests: US senator |date=29 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109181016/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gAkDaSkHWHboscdhQZwdRBt6hZnw |archivedate=9 January 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name=brownback>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-olyspy30-2008jul30,0,5823677.story |title=Sen. Brownback says China monitoring Internet access in hotels |work=Los Angeles Times |date=30 July 2008}}</ref>
The IOC also investigated complaints from the international media that the Internet at the Main Press Centre was slow and some websites remain blocked, which may disrupt reporting. This was seen when [[Amnesty International]] criticised the Chinese government for not delivering on its [[Beijing 2008 Olympic bid|Olympic promises]] of human rights; however journalists could not access the website. Additionally, websites critical of the government, or relating to Tibet and [[Falun Gong]] remain blocked at the centre. Kevan Gosper from the IOC clarified that the 'open Internet' only refers to reporting directly on the games, and not other issues relating to China.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/asia/articles/2008/07/29/internet_sites_still_blocked_for_olympic_reporters/ |title=Internet sites still blocked for Olympic reporters |work=Stephen Wade, Associated Press |date=29 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080901095221/http://www.boston.com/news/world/asia/articles/2008/07/29/internet_sites_still_blocked_for_olympic_reporters/ |archivedate=1 September 2008 }}</ref> Due to international pressure, a number of websites, notably [[BBC]], [[Amnesty International]], [[Reporters Without Borders]], and [[Apple Daily]] were unblocked.<ref name="scmplist">{{cite news| <!--Dead link: url=http://www.scmp.com/portal/site/SCMP/menuitem.2af62ecb329d3d7733492d9253a0a0a0/?vgnextoid=86217c46b2f7b110VgnVCM100000360a0a0aRCRD&ss=China&s=News |--> work= South China Morning Post|title= Beijing yields in part to pressure over internet use|accessdate=1 August 2008}}(subscription only)</ref>
When queueing for Olympic tickets descended into chaos, fighting erupted between police and ticket-buyers,<ref name="Wash1">{{cite news|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/07/25/AR2008072502866.html |work=The Washington Post| title= Olympic ticket tumult in Beijing.|author=Maureen Fan |date=26 July 2008|pages= Page A10|accessdate=21 July 2008}}</ref> including journalists from Hong Kong such as [[Cable TV Hong Kong]], [[Oriental Daily News|Hong Kong Oriental News]],<ref name="Wash1" /> and the SCMP.<ref name="Chan1">''AFP'', "[http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/362784/1/.html Police struggle to control Beijing Olympic ticket chaos]." Channelnewsasia.com (25 July 2008).</ref><ref>Sina. "[http://news.sina.com/102-000-101-101/2008-07-25/0836506267.html 香港記者踢傷奧運門票銷售現場警察.]." Sina.com (25 July 2008)</ref><ref>{{cite news |author1=Elaine Wu |author2=Kristine Kwok |author3=Mary Ann Benitez |title=Bocog regrets strong-arm tactics |date=28 July 2008 |url=http://olympics.scmp.com/Article.aspx?id=1617&section=latestnews |work=South China Morning Post |location=Hong Kong |accessdate=31 August 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090623031450/http://olympics.scmp.com/Article.aspx?id=1617&section=latestnews |archive-date=23 June 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Ting | last=Shi | title=Chaotic rush for Games tickets | date=26 July 2008 | url=http://olympics.scmp.com/Article.aspx?id=1590&section=latestnews | work=South China Morning Post | location=Hong Kong | accessdate=31 August 2008 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090623040656/http://olympics.scmp.com/Article.aspx?id=1590&section=latestnews | archive-date=23 June 2009 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Two Japanese journalists covering [[2008 Kashgar attack|bomb attacks in Xinjiang]] and a British journalist covering a Tibetan independence protest in Beijing were 'roughed up' and detained, and the British journalist claimed that his equipment was damaged. Chinese authorities apologised for the incident involving the Japanese journalists,<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/07/world/asia/07briefs-JAPANTOPROTE_BRF.html?ref=world |title= China: Japan to Protest Detentions|author=Edward Wong|work=New York Times|date=7 August 2008}}</ref> and registered concern from the British embassy and the IOC with the latter incident.<ref name=roughup>{{cite news | title=Chinese police rough up British TV crew at Olympics | date=13 August 2008 | publisher=Google News | url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5irvrCdaocfBP2v4d714WFuK3cyZA | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903002632/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5irvrCdaocfBP2v4d714WFuK3cyZA | dead-url=yes | archive-date=3 September 2008 | work=Associated Press | accessdate=17 August 2008 }}</ref>
On 14 August, the IOC urged China to allow foreign reporters to report freely at the games.<ref>{{cite news | author=Rohan Sullivan |title=IOC tells China not to obstruct reporters |date=14 August 2008 | publisher=Google News | url =http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5i3OMvEA_ehIHkQwvUsKHCWZ5QzIAD92I6LS81 | agency=Associated Press | accessdate = 17 August 2008 }}{{dead link|date=November 2012|bot=Legobot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=IOC: China should not prevent media from reporting | date=14 August 2008 | work=The Times of India | url=http://olympics.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/China_should_not_prevent_media_IOC/articleshow/3365545.cms | access-date=17 August 2008 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20120722140515/http://olympics.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/China_should_not_prevent_media_IOC/articleshow/3365545.cms | archive-date=22 July 2012 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> After the games had closed, the Foreign Correspondents Club of China (FCCC) issued a statement noting that there was "welcome progress in terms of accessibility and the number of press conferences within the Olympic facilities". However, the FCCC was "alarmed at the use of violence, intimidation and harassment outside". The club confirmed more than 30 cases of reporting interference since 25 July, and said it was checking "at least 20 other reported incidents".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24240947-2722,00.html|title=Games fell short of standards|author=Rowan Callick|date=26 August 2008|work=The Australian|access-date=24 October 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080915162044/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24240947-2722,00.html|archive-date=15 September 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Arrests of political activists === According to ''[[Business Week]]'', at least 50 Beijing human-rights activists were either arrested, put under house arrest, or banished from the capital during the Games.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.kvoa.com/Global/Story.asp?S=8894867 |title= Beijing Olympics: Adding Up the Winners and Losers |author=Dexter Roberts, Business Week |date= 25 August 2008 |publisher=Voice of America}} {{Dead link|date=February 2010}}</ref> In January 2008, AIDS and human rights activist [[Hu Jia (activist)|Hu Jia]], who was already under house arrest, was taken into custody on 27 December 2007 for "inciting subversion".<ref>{{cite news |title=Hu Jia's Fate a Test of Beijing's Human Rights Stance | date=26 February 2008 | publisher=Human Rights Watch | url =https://www.hrw.org/english/docs/2008/02/26/china18152.htm | accessdate = 16 August 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://hrw.org/english/docs/2008/02/26/china18149.htm |title=Chronology of Hu Jia's Case| publisher=Human Rights Watch }}</ref> Hu had criticised China's hosting of the Olympics by comparing it to [[Nazi Germany]] hosting the [[1936 Summer Olympics|Berlin Olympics]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://observers.france24.com/en/content/blogger_put_prison_criticising_olympic_games |title= Blogger put in prison for criticizing the Olympic Games |work= The Observers by France |date= 15 August 2008 |access-date= 15 August 2008 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080818133604/http://observers.france24.com/en/content/blogger_put_prison_criticising_olympic_games |archive-date= 18 August 2008 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> Ye Guozhu was serving a four-year sentence and was scheduled for release in 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.amnesty.org/en/appeals-for-action/permission-denied-housing-rights-activist-prison |title= Permission denied – housing rights activist in prison |publisher=Amnesty International |date= 1 April 2008}}</ref> On 26 July, his supposed release day, his family was sent an official police notice prolonging his detention. [[Amnesty International]] cited the police saying Ye "would be kept in detention to keep him and his family out of trouble until the Olympics and Paralympics were over."<ref name=mistakes/> The U.S. Embassy in Beijing expressed concern over human rights groups' reports that [[Zeng Jinyan]], blogger-wife of Hu Jia, was taken from her home on 7 August; three days later, Hua Huiqi, a leader in Beijing's underground church, was taken by security agents while on his way to church.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.wtop.com/?nid=105&sid=1464620 |title=US expresses concern for Chinese activists |agency=Associated Press| publisher=[[WTOP-FM|WTOP]] |date= 22 August 2008}}</ref>
=== Suppression of negative news === In the lead-up to the Olympics, the government issued guidelines to the local media for their reporting during the Games: political issues not directly related to the games such as Tibetan independence and social unrest in Xinjiang were not to be reported on, as were food safety issues such as "cancer-causing mineral water."<ref>Stephen Hutcheon, [http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/was-chinas-contaminated-milk-scandal-hushed-up/2008/09/15/1221330732015.html Was China's milk scandal hushed up?], [http://www.smh.com.au/news/off-the-field/the-full-list-of-edicts/2008/08/14/1218307066869.html "The full list of edicts"], ''The New Zealand Herald'' (15 September 2008)</ref> As the [[2008 Chinese milk scandal|scandal involving melamine contamination of milk]] broke in September 2008, some western media evoked suspicions that China's desire for a perfect games may have been a factor contributing towards the delayed recall of contaminated [[infant formula]],<ref name=Telegraph>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/2963808/China-accused-over-contaminated-baby-milk.html China accused over contaminated baby milk], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' (15 September 2008)</ref> which has affected 94,000<ref name=94,000>{{cite news|url=http://africa.reuters.com/world/news/usnTRE4974YX.html|title=China milk victims may have reached 94,000|author=Yu Le|agency=Reuters|date=8 October 2008|access-date=9 November 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081224232947/http://africa.reuters.com/world/news/usnTRE4974YX.html|archive-date=24 December 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> babies with [[kidney stones]] and killed at least 4 infants,<ref name=toll>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=a4krf9ZOzsh8&refer=asia China Milk Scandal Spreads; Hong Kong Girl Sickened"], [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] (21 September 2008)</ref> although the Central government denied issuing this guidance.<ref name=alerted>Al Guo, "First arrests made in tainted milk scandal", Page A4, ''South China Morning Post'' (16 September 2008)</ref> Hebei provincial vice-governor said his administration was only notified by Shijiazhuang on 8 September.<ref name=knew>Kristine Kwok, "Officials knew of tainted milk for a month", Page A4, ''South China Morning Post'' (17 September 2008)</ref> The [[World Health Organization]] asked Beijing why it took so many months for the scandal to become public, and to establish whether failure was deliberate or due to ignorance.<ref name=WHO>''AFP'', "Has there been a cover-up, WHO asks", Page A3, ''[[South China Morning Post]]'' (19 September 2008)</ref>
In the aftermath of the [[2008 Weng'an riot|Weng'an riot]], which was incited by the rape and murder of a teenage girl, [[photographs]] as well as comments on the [[Guizhou]] protest in [[chatrooms]] and [[Internet forum|forums]] were quickly [[File deletion|deleted]] by the [[Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China|mainland Internet censors]]. The government launched a campaign to defuse protest ahead of the Olympics to continue carrying out social harmony and stability. An "[[Concerns over the 2008 Summer Olympics#Domestic Issues|Olympics Stability Drive]]" was announced after the incident. Public security officials in [[Guizhou]] offered a total of 9,000 [[Chinese yuan|yuan]] (about [[US$|$]]1,300 or [[Pound sterling|£]]700 or [[Euro|€]]800) to the parents of the teenage girl, with 3,000 paid by each [[suspect]]. The father said “We will never accept an evil deal like this, we need to seek justice for our daughter.”<ref name="Asianews1">Asianews.it. "[http://www.asianews.it/index.php?l=en&art=12648&size=A Asianews.it]." ''Unrest in Guizhou as public security tries to buy the silence of the victim’s parents.'' Retrieved on 2008-07-01.</ref>
== Environmental and health issues ==
The [[United States Olympic Committee]] imported food for American athletes, citing concerns regarding the safety of food products produced in China. In particular, athletes were concerned that eating meat that was raised in China could contain enough steroids to cause the athletes to test positive for steroid use.<ref name="Steroid use">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/09/sports/othersports/09olympics.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=olympic%20food%20beijing%20committee&st=nyt&oref=slogin|title=Wary U.S. Olympians Will Bring Food to China|author=Ben Shpigel |work=The New York Times |date=9 February 2008}}</ref> Several Canadian athletes received permission to do the same. The United States Olympic Committee's plan to bring its own food to China disappointed the leader of food services for the Beijing Olympics.<ref name="USfood plan">{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/02/22/olympics.food.ap/index.html |title=China hurt over U.S. food plan for Games |date=22 February 2008|accessdate=22 February 2008 |publisher=CNN| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080225210532/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/02/22/olympics.food.ap/index.html| archivedate = 25 February 2008}}</ref>
=== Air pollution ===<!-- linked from [[Air pollution in China]] --> {{See also|Air pollution in China}} [[File:Beijing smog comparison August 2005.png|thumb|400px|Photo taken in 2005 of Beijing's air quality on a day after rain (left) and a sunny, smoggy day (right):<ref>These pictures were taken in 2005</ref> Severe air pollution in Beijing was considered a major risk for athletes' health and a potential setback to their performance.<ref name=gripe>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/science/environment/la-fg-olyair12mar12,1,3739313.story|title= Olympians air a gripe about Beijing|work=Los Angeles Times|date= 12 March 2008|pages= Page A-1 | first=Barbara | last=Demick}}</ref>]]Concern was raised over the air quality, and its potential effect on the athletes.{{Ref label|A|a|none}} Although the Beijing Municipal Government, [[Beijing 2008 Olympic bid|in its bid file in 2001]], committed to lowering air pollution, increasing environmental protection, and introducing environmental technology,<ref name="IOC report 299">{{cite web|url=http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_299.pdf |title=Report of the IOC Evaluation Commission for the Games of the XXIX Olympiad in 2008 |publisher=[[International Olympic Committee]] |page=62 |accessdate=18 July 2007 |date=15 May 2001 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031229012633/http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_299.pdf |archivedate=29 December 2003 |df=dmy }}</ref> research data show that even if the city were to dramatically cut down its emissions, pollution would still drift over from neighbouring provinces,<ref name="WSJ pollution">{{cite news |last=Oster |first=Shai |title=Will Beijing's Air Cast Pall Over Olympics?
