|work=The Wall Street Journal |date= 15 February 2007|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB117148719982908969}}</ref> upstream from which 50 percent of Beijing's air was believed to flow.<ref name="PopSci pollution article">{{cite journal | last = Mone | first = Gregory | title = Choking at the Olympics | journal=[[Popular Science]] | issue = August 2007 | pages = 33–35 | issn = 0161-7370 | laysummary = http://www.popsci.com/popsci/environment/4ec1a78d87273110vgnvcm1000004eecbccdrcrd.html | laysource = Popular Science | laydate = June 2007 }}<!--| accessdate = 18 July 2007 --></ref> Air pollution was at least two to three times higher than levels deemed safe by the [[World Health Organization]]. [[Marco Cardinale]] of the [[British Olympic Association]] has stated that air pollution coupled with heat and humidity makes it "very unlikely we'll see outstanding performances in endurance sports."<ref name="WSJ pollution"/> Despite this, Beijing committed to remove 60,000 [[taxicab|taxis]] and buses from the roads by the end of 2007 and relocate 200 local factories, including a prominent steel factory,<ref name="WSJ pollution" /> before the games began.<ref name="PopSci pollution article" /> The Chinese government provided assurances that "blue skies are a requirement not only for Beijing, but also for the places around it."<ref name="Environment">{{cite news |url=http://en.beijing2008.cn/29/47/article214024729.shtml |title=Promise of clean air during Olympics |date=13 March 2007 |accessdate=16 March 2007 |publisher=[[BOCOG]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070327125353/http://en.beijing2008.cn/29/47/article214024729.shtml |archive-date=27 March 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The [[United States Olympic Committee]] was confident that the air quality of Beijing would not be a concern for the US delegation to the games.<ref name="USOC-air">{{cite news |url=http://en.beijing2008.cn/news/official/ioc/n214119154.shtml |title=USOC official: air quality not a concern for U.S. Olympic delegation in Beijing |date=3 August 2007 |accessdate=3 August 2007 |publisher=BOCOG |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071101063350/http://en.beijing2008.cn/news/official/ioc/n214119154.shtml |archive-date=1 November 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Nevertheless, the IOC's medical commission analysed air-quality data recorded by the Beijing Environment Protection Bureau in August, when test athletic events were held in the Chinese capital. The commission found that outdoor endurance events—defined as those that include at least an hour of continuous, high-intensity physical effort—may pose some risk.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120577799162242425|title=Olympic Worry in the Air|date=18 March 2008 |accessdate=23 March 2008 |work=The Wall Street Journal | first1=Sky | last1=Canaves | first2=Christopher | last2=Rhoads}}</ref>
In spite of such efforts, several countries indicated that their athletes would arrive at the games as late as possible to limit exposure to pollution.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6950883.stm|title=WHO fears over Beijing pollution|date=17 August 2007|accessdate=17 August 2007 |publisher=BBC}}</ref> Many teams set up offshore training camps in neighbouring countries to avoid the pollution.<ref name=gripe/> The pollution prompted several athletes to change events or opt out: for example, [[Ethiopia]]n long-distance runner [[Haile Gebrselassie]] withdrew from the [[Athletics at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon|marathon]] and ran the [[Athletics at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's 10,000 metres|10,000 meters]] instead, to reduce the risk of harm to himself because of his [[asthma]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/olympics/athletics/7287578.stm| title=Gebrselassie opts out of marathon| publisher=[[BBC Sport]]| date=10 March 2008 }}</ref> and Belgian tennis player [[Justine Henin]] announced nearly a year before the games that she would not compete for the same reasons.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tennis/news/story?id=3095205 | title=Henin trying to manage asthma, might skip Olympics |publisher=ESPN | date=4 August 2008 | accessdate=15 October 2008}}</ref>
In July 2008, stricter emergency pollution controls were introduced, including suspending production at more factories and coal-fired power plants, lowering the number of cars on the road and expanding driving restrictions to nearby [[Tianjin]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/01/sports/olympics/01china.html?emc=tnt&tntemail1=y | title=China Announces More Pollution Controls |work=The New York Times |date=1 August 2008 | first=Jim | last=Yardley | accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref> In early July, Beijing ordered 40 factories in [[Tianjin]] and 300 factories in [[Tangshan]] to begin suspending operations in an effort to reduce air pollution.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/7491456.stm |title=China to close plants over Games| publisher=BBC| date= 5 July 2008}}</ref> On 20 July, a major temporary air pollution control plan began: additional factories were shut down; there were license plate restrictions which allowed Beijing motorists to drive on alternate days only, depending on whether the last number on their license plate was odd or even, to reduce daily traffic by two million vehicles.<ref>A similar approach was used for other events such as the [[2015 China Victory Day Parade]] and the [[2016 G20 Hangzhou summit]].</ref> Despite the program, by 28 July the ''[[China Daily]]'' reported that Beijing's skies remained alarmingly polluted and that authorities were considering emergency measures during the Games.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/29/sports/olympics/29china.html|title=Beijing Weighs Added Pollution Plans for Olympics|date=29 July 2008 |accessdate=29 July 2008 |work=The New York Times | first=Jim | last=Yardley}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2008-07/28/content_6880332.htm|title=Beijing mulls emergency green plan for Games|date=28 July 2008 |accessdate=28 July 2008 |work=China Daily }}</ref>
<div class="center">{{2008 Summer Olympics air quality}}</div>
As the Games began, air quality in Beijing improved significantly against prior expectations. Air quality throughout the Games recorded [[Air Pollution Index#Mainland China|API]] scores under 100, the official target. Of the 16 days of the Games, ten days recorded 'Grade I' and six days recorded 'Grade II' air quality in Chinese standards.<ref name=xinhua1>{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-08/19/content_9501386.htm|title=Official: air quality for Olympics Beijing's best in a decade|agency=Xinhua News Agency|date= 19 August 2008}}</ref> Media concerns of air quality has also subsided as the Games progressed. However, a 28 July 2008 [[Greenpeace]] report stated that average concentration of [[atmospheric particulate matter]] in Beijing was still twice the levels the [[World Health Organization]] considers safe.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/node/14937 |title=Beijing Pollution Still Twice WHO Levels: Greenpeace |agency=Agence France-Presse |publisher=abs-cbn news |date=28 July 2008 |access-date=14 October 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090623144907/http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/node/14937 |archive-date=23 June 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Although observers doubted the performance in endurance events due to air quality, humidity and temperature, the men's 10 km and marathon events did set new Olympic records. The Chinese authority pledged to continue their environmental efforts after the Games and pointed to their ¥140 billion investment in the past ten years as evidence of their determination. After witnessing the success of their efforts, some of the temporary measures during the Games are being considered for permanent enforcement.<ref name=xinhua1/> <!-- Nevertheless, on 19 August environmental officials{{Who|date=October 2008}} said pollution levels had met expected standards every day of the Olympics.{{Fact|date=October 2008}} On 30 September, the [[Government of the People's Republic of China|Chinese government]] announced that a 'trial version' of milder traffic restrictions similar to the ones imposed during the Games would be put in place.{{Fact|date=October 2008}} These include restricting 30% of government vehicles from the road each day, and having all vehicles banned from the road one day per week based on license plate number.{{Fact|date=October 2008}}-->
=== Pollution threats to sailing events === At the end of May 2008, two months before the start of the Olympics, a "[[red tide]]" (a type of [[algal bloom]]) was found to be developing. It began choking large stretches of the Qingdao near to the venue for the sailing events.<ref name=algae>{{cite news | title=Chinese race to clear algae from Olympic sailing venue | date=30 June 2008 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/jun/30/pollution.olympicgames2008 | work=The Guardian | accessdate=27 August 2008 | location=London | first=Tania | last=Branigan}}</ref> While algae blooms are known to develop in nutrient-rich water, often as a result of chemical pollution, run-off from heavy fertiliser use or untreated sewerage;<ref name=promises>{{cite news | title=Beijing promises no algae blooms in Games waters | date=3 July 2008 | url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/PEK365823.htm | agency=Reuters AlertNet | accessdate=27 August 2008 }}</ref> Qingdao's Ocean and Fishing Bureau said the particular temperature and salinity of sea water had been responsible in this case.<ref name=algae/>
Officials in Qingdao achieved their own target of 15 July to clear the algae in the vicinity of the venue.<ref name=promises/> The task force that cleaned-up more than a million tonnes of algae were said to number 1,200 boats<ref name=promises/> and many thousands of troops and volunteers.<ref>{{cite news | title=China says Olympic sailing venue now algae-free | date=15 July 2008 | url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/PEK211659.htm | agency=Reuters AlertNet | accessdate=27 August 2008 }}</ref>
A {{convert|2|km2|adj=on}} [[oil spill|oil slick]] was discovered off the coast of [[Qingdao]] on 11 August.<ref>{{cite news |title=Officials monitor oil slick off sailing venue |date=13 August 2008 | publisher=Google News | url =http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5go0swu60s1xyEhmLPODj1Ye1SRqQD92H5UE00 | agency=Associated Press | accessdate = 19 August 2008 }}{{dead link|date=November 2012|bot=Legobot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Chen | last=Qian | title=Oil slick found near Olympic sailing venue |date=13 August 2008 | url =http://www.shanghaidaily.com/sp/article/2008/200808/20080813/article_370266.htm | work=Shanghai Daily | accessdate = 19 August 2008}}</ref> Officials said that the oil would not affect Olympic sailing,<ref>{{cite news | title=Oil film off the coast will not affect Olympic sailing |date=13 August 2008 |url =http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-08/13/content_9249624.htm | agency=Xinhua News Agency | accessdate = 19 August 2008 }}</ref> and all the sailing events proceeded as scheduled.
== Tourism == Prior to the Games, officials anticipated two million tourists, of which one-third would be from overseas. However, actual volume of visitors fell 9.2% year-on-year. Chinese officials cited the [[2008 Sichuan earthquake|Sichuan earthquake]], [[2008 Tibetan unrest|riots in Tibet]], [[2008 Summer Olympics torch relay#Torch security|torch relay protests]] and the [[subprime mortgage crisis]] as factors.<ref name=vacancies>{{cite web|url= http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/aug2008/gb20080819_224722.htm?chan=top+news_top+news+index_global+business |date=19 August 2008 |title= Olympic Vacancies Haunt Beijing Hotels|work=Business Week|author=Chi-Chu Tschang }}</ref> Locally, many people anticipated that Beijing would be too crowded during the Games. Businesses avoided scheduling meetings during these two weeks, and potential Chinese visitors decided to stay at home and watch the events on TV.
Initially, many hotel owners invested heavily for the Olympics.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.latimes.com/sports/olympics/la-fi-olympics22-2008aug22,0,5816776.story|title=Olympics disappoint China business owners| author=Don Lee|work=Los Angeles |date=22 August 2008}}</ref> Many anticipated bookings in the 70% to 80% level, and room prices jumped as much as ten times the regular level.<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/travelnews/2456877/Beijing-hotels-drop-prices-as-low-turn-out-hits-Olympic-Games.html |title=Beijing hotels drop prices as low turn-out hits Olympic Games |work=The Daily Telegraph |author=Charles Starmer-Smith|date=25 July 2008 | location=London}}</ref> Occupancy of 77% was reported for luxury hotels in early August. For 4-star hotels and lower, occupancy of 40% led to price reductions, although still at three times the regular price.<ref name=vacancies/> In July, [[Air China]], the nation's flagship carrier, also saw its international passenger traffic fall by 19% from a year earlier.<ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref name=csm1>{{cite web|url=http://features.csmonitor.com/olympics08/2008/08/18/for-beijing%e2%80%99s-businesses-the-games-fall-short-of-gold/ |title=For Beijing's businesses, the Games fall short of gold |author=Simon Montlake & Peter Ford | work=The Christian Science Monitor|date=18 August 2008}}</ref>
Hoteliers blamed the lack of visitors on increased security measures and the tightening of visa rules and for driving out thousands of itinerant foreigners and overseas students living in Beijing. Visa requirements introduced in April required foreign visitors to have proof of their accommodation and return flight when applying to enter China. One foreign Olympics consultant was quoted as saying "they made it hard to get tickets and hard to get visas. The impression they gave was that they didn’t want foreigners to come".<ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref name=csm1/>
According to the Beijing Olympic Organising Committee (BOCOG), the 6.8 million tickets to the Games were sold out. The prevalence of empty seats at many events caused journalists and visitors to be suspicious about these claims.<ref name=sky>{{cite web|url= http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Empty-Olympics-China-Busses-In-Locals-To-Fill-Beijing-Seats/Article/200808215076213?lpos=World%2BNews_3&lid=ARTICLE_15076213_Empty%2BOlympics%253A%2BChina%2BBusses%2BIn%2BLocals%2BTo%2BFill%2BBeijing%2BSeats |title=Empty Olympics: China Busses In Locals To Fill Beijing Seats | publisher=Sky News |date=13 August 2008| accessdate=29 August 2008}}</ref> Beijing Olympic organisers were said to have given some 2.7 million tickets to officials and corporate sponsors, many of whom did not attend the events. A mainland journal suggested that the day-tickets without right of re-entry was also part of the problem. In one instance, people in the audience left the stadium after the Chinese women's volleyball match, but they were not allowed back when they found out there was another game.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/beijing_olympics/story/0,27313,24173232-5016818,00.html |title= Officials urged to open venues |work=The Australian |date=13 August 2008|accessdate=29 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20080812/BEIJING_venues_080812/20080812?s_name=beijing2008&no_ads= | title= Ticket scalping big in Beijing, despite empty seats|publisher=Canadian TV| date=12 August 2008|accessdate=29 August 2008}}</ref> A senior BOCOG official expressed concern about the empty seats, saying that the hot, humid weather could have caused the poor turnout. Officials admitted to bussing in locals or "cheerleaders" to fill seats.<ref name=sky/> The empty seats angered athletes of countries outside China, who had been told that 80 percent of tickets had been reserved for the Chinese.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/local/sport/olympics/empty-seats-infuriate-swimmers-families/1241525.aspx|title=Empty seats infuriate swimmers' families|work=[[The Canberra Times]]|date=12 August 2008|accessdate=29 August 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080817144247/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/local/sport/olympics/empty-seats-infuriate-swimmers-families/1241525.aspx|archive-date=17 August 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Despite early warnings published by ''[[The Guardian]]''<ref name="guardian">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/09/olympicgames2008.internet |author=Jamie Doward| title=How boom in rogue ticket websites fleeces Britons|work=The Observer|date= 9 March 2008 | location=London}}</ref> and efforts by official ticketing coordinators, more than $6 million in [[Internet fraud|fraudulent]] tickets were sold by an illegitimate [[online ticket brokering|online ticket broker]].<ref name=swindle>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/latest-news/ticket-swindle-leaves-trail-of-losers/2008/08/03/1217701854125.html |title=Ticket swindle leaves trail of losers|author=Jacquelin Magnay|work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date= 4 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. attorney investigates UK Olympics ticket 'Touts' and Canadian company Roadtrips.com|url=http://www.ticketnews.com/Olympic-tickets-mess-attorney-investigates-UK-Olympics-Touts-Roadtrips9825432|date=25 September 2008|publisher=TicketNews|author=Ian Hough & Alfred Branch Jr.|access-date=27 September 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927145304/http://www.ticketnews.com/Olympic-tickets-mess-attorney-investigates-UK-Olympics-Touts-Roadtrips9825432|archive-date=27 September 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Concerns and controversies over the 2010 Winter Olympics]] * [[Concerns and controversies over the 2010 Commonwealth Games]] * [[Controversies at the 2012 Summer Olympics]]
== References ==
=== Notes === {{refbegin}} <ol type="a"> <li>{{Note label|A|a|none}}Poor-quality air in China contributes to the death of about 400,000 Chinese annually. [[Ozone]] and fine [[particulate]] matter—bits of [[carbon]], [[sulfate]]s, and industrial [[by-product]]s— were the two biggest pollution threats to the athletes in 2008. When high ozone levels are present, lungs are not able to absorb as much air, causing coughing, wheezing, or headaches.<ref name="PopSci pollution article" /></li> </ol> {{refend}}
=== Citations === {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Olympic Games controversies}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Concerns And Controversies Over The 2008 Summer Olympics}} [[Category:2008 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic Games controversies|*2008]] [[Category:2008 controversies]] [[Category:Foreign relations of China]]

page.title: Customs Union between the EU and the UK

revision.text:
An '''EU-UK Customs Union''' is a proposal to have a [[Customs Union]] between a post [[Brexit]] United Kingdom and the [[European Union]].
As the United Kingdom is leaving the European Union, then it will not be able to participate in the [[EU's Common Commercial Policy]] and so continued membership of the [[EU Customs Union]] is not seen by most commentators as being viable. Some commentators have suggested that there should be a bilateral Customs Union between the European Union and the UK on the same model of the [[European Union–Turkey Customs Union]].<ref>[https://www.channel4.com/news/factcheck/factcheck-what-are-the-options-for-the-irish-border-after-brexit What are the options for the Irish border after Brexit?], Georgina Lee, [[Channel 4]], 29 Nov 2017</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/uk-wales-politics-42230485/brexit-customs-union-would-solve-irish-border-carwyn-jones-says Brexit: Customs union would solve Irish border, Carwyn Jones says] First Minister of Wales, [[Carwyn Jones]], speaking to BBC Wales, 04 Dec 2017</ref>
Some critics believe that the Customs Union between the UK and the EU is a minor part of resolving cross border delays as it does not on its own deal with Single Market issues or the ability of non EU HGV drivers to drive on EU roads.<ref>[https://www.ft.com/content/b4458652-f42d-11e6-8758-6876151821a6 Turkey border gridlock hints at pain to come for Brexit Britain] [[The Financial Times]], February 16, 2017</ref>
[[Jeremy Corbyn]], the leader of the [[Labour Party (UK)]], has backed an EU-UK Customs Union.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-43189878</ref> The [[House of Lords]] voted in April 2018 to force a negotiation of a Customs Union between the EU and the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-43812360|title=Brexit: Ministers suffer first defeat on EU Withdrawal Bill|publisher=BBC News|date=18 April 2018|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref>
==References==
{{reflist}}
{{EU-stub}}
[[Category:Brexit]] [[Category:Customs unions]]

'''Donnie Davies''' is a fictional character who is featured in a number of websites. Davies describes himself as an [[Anabaptist]] youth [[pastor]], "[[ex-gay|reformed homosexual]]", and lead singer for the band [[Evening Service]]. Davies and the band were unknown until the release of the music video for the anti-homosexuality song "The Bible Says" on the [[Internet]] in January 2007. Davies claims affiliation with the organization Love God's Way Ministries, which launched a website around the same time as the release of the video. He is also the founder and spokesman for the C.H.O.P.S. program. The acronym stands for "Changing Homosexuals into Ordinary People Sexually". C.H.O.P.S. is promoted through Love God's Way's website.
His video was removed from YouTube.com without comment from the company and has been removed by Google. It has since been put back up on YouTube.<ref name="Washington Blade">{{cite web|title=The Latest! |date=29 January 2007 |url=http://www.washblade.com/thelatest/thelatest.cfm?blog_id=11101 |publisher=The Washington Blade |accessdate=2007-02-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928014409/http://www.washblade.com/thelatest/thelatest.cfm?blog_id=11101 |archivedate=September 28, 2007 }}</ref>
==Controversy== Much of the initial controversy revolved around whether or not Davies is genuinely promoting an anti-gay agenda, or if this is a [[viral marketing]] campaign. Some [[gay rights]] advocates acknowledge that as a spoof it is humorous, but claim the message behind it is still as malicious as someone who seriously possessed the opinion.<ref name="Washington Blade"/><ref name="Dan Savage">{{cite web | title = Dan Savage, "Slog" | url =http://www.thestranger.com/blog/2007/01/donnie_davies_third_times_the_charm | publisher = The Stranger | date = 28 January 2007 | accessdate = 2007-02-02}}</ref><ref name="Philadelphia Weekly">{{cite web|title=One Big Conn: When Viral Marketing Misses Its Mark |date=31 January 2007 |url=http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/view.php?id=13936 |publisher=Philadelphia Weekly |accessdate=2007-02-02 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070210162142/http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/view.php?id=13936 |archivedate=2007-02-10 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Debate has quickly risen regarding the authenticity of Davies' youth ministry activities, the band Evening Service, and the organization Love God's Way ranging from entertainment publications such as ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]''<ref name="Spin Magazine">{{cite web | title = Donnie Davies: Real McCoy or Offensive Gag? | date = 24 January 2007 | url = http://www.spin.com/features/everybodystalkingabout/2007/01/070124_eveningservice/ | publisher = Spin | accessdate = 2007-02-02 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070202031643/http://www.spin.com/features/everybodystalkingabout/2007/01/070124_eveningservice/ | archivedate = 2 February 2007 | df = }}</ref> to thousands of personal [[blogs]][http://www.google.com/search?q=%22Donnie+Davies%22+&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8&rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&client=firefox-a] Some in the [[blogosphere]] maintained that Davies was truly seeking to "convert" other homosexuals to [[heterosexuality]] {{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}. Others considered Davies ministry and the video part of a carefully designed [[hoax]] mocking the [[Christian right|Christian Conservative]] community. Other controversies involve the claims on Donnie's website of what music "will make you gay." This included some of his own music.<ref name="Cinema Blend">{{cite web | title = Music Makes You Gay? | date = 30 January 2007 | url =http://www.cinemablend.com/music/RANT-Liking-Good-Music-Makes-You-Gay-2587.html | publisher = Cinema Blend | accessdate = 2007-02-02}}</ref>
Gay rights organizations, such as Heartstrong,<ref>[http://www.heartstrong.org/HeartStrong/DonnieDaviesHates.html Heartstrong]</ref> are addressing this as a serious threat to the gay community.
Several blogs speculated that Donnie Davies was a character created by [[Improvisational theatre|improv]] actor Todd Quillen<ref name="Joe.My.God.">{{cite web | title = Donnie Davies = Todd Quillen? | date = 25 January 2007 | url =http://joemygod.blogspot.com/2007/01/donnie-davies-todd-quillen.html | publisher = Joe.My.God. | accessdate = 2011-08-17}}</ref> or out gay director [[Jason Bolicki]].<ref name="Slog">{{cite web | title = Donnie “God Hates a Fag” Davies: Radar Weighs In | date = 25 January 2007 | url =http://slog.thestranger.com/2007/01/donnie_god_hates_a_fag_davies_radar_weig | publisher = The Stranger | accessdate = 2011-08-17}}</ref>
On 9 February 2007, [[MTV News]] Webcam Correspondent posted a video on [[YouTube]], proving Donnie Davies to be a character played by actor [[Joey Oglesby]]. The piece interviewed the actor and director and included their surprise that anyone took the video as being serious.
==See also== * [[Brüno]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.eveningservice.com/TakeMyHand Donnie's new video, Take My Hand] *[http://www.donniedavies.com Donnie Davies' webpage] * [http://www.eveningservice.com Evening Service] * [http://www.lovegodsway.org Love God's Way Ministries] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070329003340/http://2007.sxsw.com/music/showcases/band/51893.html Donnie Davies w/ Evening Service to Perform at SXSW in Austin, TX] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3egOusDlgKI Webcam Correspondent 3: The Online Hoax, Donnie Davies?] * [http://www.exgay.com Heartstrong]

{{short description|Locomotive class}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox locomotive |name=EMD G12 series |powertype=[[Diesel-electric]] |image=Sl train.jpg |caption=[[Sri Lanka Railways M2|Class M2]] 570 - "ALBERTA" in Sri Lanka |builder=[[Electro-Motive Diesel|General Motors Electro-Motive Division]] (USA),
[[General Motors Diesel]] (Canada)
[[Clyde Engineering]] (Australia) |builddate=1953-1968 |aarwheels=[[A1A-A1A]] and [[AAR wheel arrangement#B-B|B-B]] |gauge={{track gauge|1000mm}}
{{track gauge|3ft6in}}
{{track gauge|ussg}}
{{track gauge|5ft3in}}
{{track gauge|5ft6in}} |primemover=[[EMD 567]] |transmission=[[Diesel-electric transmission|Electric]] |enginetype=[[Two-stroke engine|two-stroke]] [[V12 engine|V12]] [[Diesel engine|diesel]] |totalproduction=B-B version: 670
A1A-A1A version: 300
C-C version: 66 |cylindercount= 12 |cylindersize={{convert|8.5|x|10|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |locoweight={{convert|107|LT|t ST}} |fuelcap={{convert|2840|l|USgal impgal}} |poweroutput= {{convert|1310|or|1425|bhp|abbr=on}} |tractiveeffort={{convert|19100|kg-f|kN lbf|1|abbr=on}} |buildmodel=G12 |disposition= Most [[scrap]]ped, many preserved, some still in service }} The '''EMD G12''' was a class of locomotive built by [[GM-EMD]], and its Canadian affiliate [[General Motors Diesel]]. In addition, Australian licensee [[Clyde Engineering]] built ten locomotives for New Zealand in 1957, five for Hong Kong, 23 for Queensland, 14 for Western Australia and seven for [[BHP Billiton|BHP]]. Australian licensee [[Commonwealth Engineering]] also built 42 for [[Queensland Rail]] in 1964–66. Many examples were built in the 1950-1960s for railroads all over the world. They are powered by [[EMD 567|EMD 12-567C]] prime movers rated at {{convert|1250|hp|kW|abbr=on}}. Some have been rebuilt with [[EMD 645]] engines. ==Original Owners== ===Bo-Bo version=== ====Australia==== * 7 [[BHP Billiton#Broken Hill Proprietary Company|Broken Hill Proprietary Company]] – [[BHP Whyalla DE class|DE class]] ====Brazil==== A total of 241 locomotives: * 2 [[Estrada de Ferro de Goiás]] 5201–5202 * 30 Mogiana Railway 3001–3030 * 43 [[Estrada de Ferro Noroeste do Brasil]] 1101–1143 * 17 [[Rede de Viação Paraná-Santa Catarina]] * 18 [[São Paulo Railway]] 700–717 * 25 [[Rede Mineira de Viação]] 2201–2207, 2217–2228 * 71 [[Viação Férrea do Rio Grande do Sul]] 2121–2145, 2161–2168, 6169–6206 * 35 [[Estrada de Ferro Vitória a Minas]] 531–565 ====Canada==== * 2 [[London and Port Stanley Railway]] L4, L5 * 1 [[General Motors Diesel]] demonstrator 7707 (to Sweden as [[Statens Järnvägar]] T42 in service between 1956 and 1983http://www.trafikverket.se/jarnvagsmuseum/publik-trafik/museitag/vara-tag/Diesel/T42-205/) ====Chile==== * 3 [[Andes Copper Mining]] 81–83 ====Egypt==== * 97 [[Egyptian Railways]] 3701–3797.{{cite book |last=Hughes |first=Hugh |isbn=0-9503469-7-7 |year=1981 |title=Middle East Railways |place=Harrow |publisher=Continental Railway Circle|page=26}} During the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], Israel captured 3712, 3715, 3766 and 3795, which were appropriated to Israel Railways stock. ====Israel==== * 23 [[Israel Railways]] 104–126,{{cite book |last=Cotterell |first=Paul |isbn=0-905878-04-3 |year=1984 |title=The Railways of Palestine and Israel |place=Abingdon |publisher=[http://www.tourretpublishing.com Tourret Publishing] |page=136}} some since rebuilt with [[EMD 645|12-645E]] engines. After the 1967 Six-Day War, four captured Egyptian G12s were renumbered 127–130.Cotterell, 1984, page 103 ==== Iran ==== * 137 [[Islamic Republic of Iran Railways]] 40.01–40.137 * Driver cab of most of the active units have been changed to full view like GT26. * Railway Research Center ([[MATRAI]]) has converted one of G12 loco to [[Hybrid locomotive]] in 2001 with AC drive. ====Hong Kong==== * 5 [[Kowloon-Canton Railway Corporation]] No. 51–55 ** 52–55 re-sold to [[CFCL Australia|Chicago Freight Car Leasing Australia]] as TL152–TL155 ** 51 "Sir Alexander", named after by-then governor of Hong Kong in 1955, [[Alexander Grantham]], was donated and preserved in [[Hong Kong Railway Museum]] after retirement and restoration{{cite web|url=http://www.heritagemuseum.gov.hk/documents/2199315/2199693/Diesel-Electric-Engine-No.51_E.pdf|title=Diesel Electric Engine No. 51 - "Sir Alexander"|access-date=30 September 2017|publisher=Hong Kong Heritage Museum}} ====Mexico==== * 84 [[Ferrocarriles Nacionales de México]] 5806–5889 ====Netherlands==== * 5 [[Dutch State Mines]] SM 151-155 (Built in 1956-1959 under license as Henschel G12 in Germany). In 1970 sold to the [[Nederlandse Spoorwegen]] as series NS 2901-2905. In 1975 sold to Ferrocarriles de Vía Estrecha in Spain. ====South Korea==== * 25 [[Korean National Railways]] 4001–4015, 4101–4110 ====Nigeria==== * 25 [[Nigerian Railways]] 1101–1125 ====Norway==== * 2 [[Sydvaranger]] 1, DE101 – [[Sydvaranger G12|G12]] (used on the [[Kirkenes–Bjørnevatn Line]], 1954–97) ====Sri Lanka==== * 2 [[Sri Lanka Railways]]. [[Sri Lanka Railways M2|Class M2C]] 626–627 (Before 2010 it used only for upcountry between Rathmalana, Colombo- Kandy, Badulla.) ====Venezuela==== * Government Coal Mines 01–03 ===A1A-A1A version=== ====Argentina==== [[File:Ferroexpreso Pampeano 4.jpg|thumbnail|A [[Ferroexpreso Pampeano]] EMD G12 on the [[Sarmiento Railway]].]] * 25 [[Ferrocarril Domingo Faustino Sarmiento|Sarmiento Railway]] 4501–4525, later 6551-6575. ====Australia==== * 13 [[Queensland Rail]] [[Queensland Railways 1400 class|1400 class]] ====Brazil==== A total of 26 locomotives: * 6 [[Rede Mineira de Viação]] 2708–2712 * 20 [[Viação Férrea do Rio Grande do Sul]] 2101–2120 ====Indonesia==== * 11 [[Kereta Api Indonesia|Indonesian State Railways]] BB201 01–BB201 11 ====Mexico==== * 6 [[Ferrocarriles Nacionales de México]] 5800–5805 ====New Zealand==== * 146 [[New Zealand Railways Department|New Zealand Government Railways]] 1400–1545 – [[New Zealand DA class locomotive]] ====Sri Lanka==== [[File:M2loco.jpg|thumb|Sri Lanka Railways Class M2D 628]] *12 [[Sri Lanka Railways]].{{cite web|url=http://www.infolanka.com/org/mrail/locos2.html|title=Mainline Diesel-Electrics|website=infolanka.com}} All except M2 571 still in daily operation (1). Classified as [[Sri Lanka Railways M2|Class M2]] ** Class M2 569–573 One Engine (As locomotives are called by Sri Lankans) (M2 571) destroyed by terrorism. ** Class M2A 591–593 ** Class M2B 594–595 ** Class M2D 628–629 ====Taiwan==== * 52 [[Taiwan Railway Administration]] R21–R72; some of their engines were replaced to 12-645E. R56–59: sent to [[Malawi Railways]] in July 2006. ====USA==== * 1 [[Electro-Motive Diesel|Electro-Motive Division]] demonstrator 1956 ===Co-Co version=== ====Australia==== A total of 66 locomotives: * 10 [[Queensland Railways 1450 class|1450 class]] * 42 [[Queensland Railways 1460 class|1460 class]] (later on-sold to [[Tranz Rail]] and converted to [[New Zealand DQ and QR class locomotives|DQ class]] locomotives for use in New Zealand and [[Tasmania]]). * 14 [[Western Australian Government Railways]] [[WAGR A class (diesel)|A class]] ==Gallery== Image:KCR-siralexander.JPG|[[Kowloon-Canton Railway Corporation|Kowloon-Canton Railway Corporation (KCRC)]] 51, a G12 built by Clyde Engineering (serial number 55-59 of 1955), photographed in the Hong Kong Railway Museum, November 2005. File:EMD G12, No.55, R. D. Walker, Tai Po Market Station, Jun 2000.jpg|KCRC EMD G12, No.55 (R. D. Walker), at Tai Po Market Station, Hong Kong, June 2000.
