{{coord|42.81057|N|74.90048|W|type:landmark_region:US-NY|display=title}} [[File:Glimmerglass Opera.JPG|thumb|300px|Alice Busch Opera Theater]] The '''Glimmerglass Festival''' (formerly known as '''Glimmerglass Opera''') is an [[opera]] company which was founded in 1975 by Peter Macris and presents an annual season of operas at the '''Alice Busch Opera Theater''' on [[Otsego Lake (New York)|Otsego Lake]] eight miles (13 km) north of [[Cooperstown, New York]], [[United States]].
The summer-only season usually consists of four productions performed in rotating repertory. Glimmerglass is well known for producing new, lesser-known, and rare works, many of which in years past have been co-produced with the [[New York City Opera]].<ref>{{cite news|title=At City Opera, an Innovator Bows Out|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/06/arts/music/06tomm.html|work=The New York Times|date=2007-05-06|first=Anthony|last=Tommasini|authorlink=Anthony Tommasini}}</ref> It is the second-largest summer opera festival in the United States, led by Artistic and General Director [[Francesca Zambello]].
==History== Until 2011, the company operated under the name Glimmerglass Opera. The company presented its first season in the summer of 1975, when four performances of ''[[La bohème]]'' were staged in the auditorium of the Cooperstown High School. In the years since, it has grown considerably and now offers more than 40 performances of four operas, nearly always in new productions, each summer.
Operas have been performed in repertory since 1990. For the first seventeen seasons, all operas were sung in English; since 1992 they have, with some exceptions, been performed in their original language with [[Surtitles|projected titles]] in English.
Several works have had their American or world premieres at Glimmerglass; the 1999 season featured the world premiere of ''Central Park'', three one-act operas performed as a single work. The triptych was jointly commissioned by Glimmerglass Opera, New York City Opera, and Thirteen/[[WNET]]'s ''[[Great Performances]]'', which telecast it on [[PBS]] in January 2000. The telecast was nominated for an [[Emmy Award]].
Paul Kellogg was the General Director of Glimmerglass Opera from 1979 to 1996 and the Artistic Director from 1996 to 2006.<ref>{{cite news|title=City Opera Appoints a Director|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/12/arts/city-opera-appoints-a-director.html|work=The New York Times|date=1996-01-12|first=Allan|last=Kozinn|authorlink=Allan Kozinn}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Paul Kellogg to Retire From New York City Opera and Glimmerglass Posts| url=http://www.playbillarts.com/news/article/2869.html | work=Playbill Arts | date=2005-09-15}}</ref> Stewart Robertson was music director of Glimmerglass Opera from 1988 to 2006.<ref>{{cite news | title=Glimmerglass Opera Music Director to Step Down | url=http://www.andante.com/article/article.cfm?id=26244 | agency=Associated Press | date=2005-12-02 | accessdate=2008-10-22 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081116111845/http://www.andante.com/article/article.cfm?id=26244 | archivedate=2008-11-16 | df= }}</ref> In October 2008, Glimmerglass Opera announced the appointment of David Angus as the company's next music director, starting in the summer of 2010.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.glimmerglass.org/PDF/Press%209.1/GGO%20Announces%20Music%20Director.pdf | title=Glimmerglass Opera Appoints Music Director | publisher=Glimmerglass Opera | date=20 October 2008 | accessdate=2008-10-22 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100923105652/http://glimmerglass.org/PDF/Press%209.1/GGO%20Announces%20Music%20Director.pdf | archivedate=23 September 2010 | df= }}</ref> [[Francesca Zambello]] became artistic and general director of the newly renamed Glimmerglass Festival in 2011.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.operanews.com/Opera_News_Magazine/2011/5/Features/The_Company_She_Keeps.html|title=The Company She Keeps|date=May 2011|volume=75|number=11|work=[[Opera News]]|author=David Belcher}}</ref>
{{Citation needed span|date=January 2015|text=The Young American Artists Program, established in 1988, brings singers in the first stages of their professional careers to study and perform at Glimmerglass. These young artists are chosen annually from hundreds of applicants from throughout the United States. In addition to rehearsing and performing, Young Artists receive musical coaching, attend classes in diction and acting, and are given instruction in such non-performing skills as audition techniques, role preparation, and the business aspects of managing a career. Administrators from many of the world's leading opera houses visit Glimmerglass throughout the summer and hear the Young Artists in performance. In the course of the summer each Young Artist gives a solo song recital at venues in Cooperstown and nearby Cherry Valley, a feature of the Glimmerglass season that has become extremely popular with opera patrons and the local community.}}
==Alice Busch Opera Theater== The Glimmerglass Festival's Alice Busch Opera Theater, which opened in June 1987, was built on {{convert|43|acre|0}} of farmland donated by Tom Goodyear, its first chairman. The 914-seat theater<ref>{{cite web|title=ALICE BUSCH OPERA THEATER|url=http://glimmerglass.org/your-visit/glimmerglass/allice-busch-opera-theater/|website=The Glimmerglass Festival|publisher=The Glimmerglass Festival|accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref> is notable for its pastoral setting, for being the first American opera house built since 1966, and for its sliding walls, closed only while singers are on-stage and in foul weather. The Theater was designed by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates.
The new theater was built to move the performances from a high school auditorium with poor acoustics and sight lines and no orchestra pit to a building with an interior designed specifically for opera performances. The exterior design was inspired by local farm buildings to fit with the surrounding landscape and to promote a less formal and more relaxed atmosphere suitable for a summer theater. For environmental and cost efficiencies, the building was designed to use only natural ventilation, without any mechanical heating or cooling.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Theater of Architecture|last = Hardy|first = Hugh|publisher = Princeton Architectural Press|year = 2013|isbn = |location = New York|pages = 185–189}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Open-air opera|last = Anderson|first = Grace|date = 1988|journal = Architectural Record|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |pages = 90–93|issue = August}}</ref>
==Recent festival seasons== The Festival's 2010 season featured four new productions, including Copland's ''[[The Tender Land]]'', and Handel's ''[[Tolomeo]]''. During the 2011 season [[Luigi Cherubini|Cherubini]]'s ''[[Médée (Cherubini)|Médée]]'' was presented. Also, a double bill featuring the world premiere of ''A Blizzard on Marblehead Neck'', with music by [[Jeanine Tesori]] set to [[Tony Kushner]]'s libretto (a story inspired by the life of [[Eugene O'Neill]]) along with ''Later the Same Evening'', a one-act opera based on characters in five of [[Edward Hopper]]'s paintings with a score by [[John Musto]] from a libretto by Mark Campbell.
In 2012, the festival featured Verdi's ''[[Aida]]'', Lully's ''[[Armide (Lully)|Armide]]'', Kurt Weill's ''[[Lost in the Stars]]'' and the musical ''[[The Music Man]]''.<ref>{{cite press release| url=http://www.glimmerglass.org/press/news-releases/current/the-glimmerglass-festival-announces-2012-season/| title=The Glimmerglass Festival Announces 2012 Season| publisher=Glimmerglass Opera| date=14 June 2011| accessdate=2011-06-14| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111018175559/http://www.glimmerglass.org/press/news-releases/current/the-glimmerglass-festival-announces-2012-season/| archivedate=18 October 2011| df=}}</ref> ''Armide'' was presented in collaboration with [[Opera Atelier]] of Toronto, Canada, and ''Lost in the Stars'' presented in collaboration with [[Cape Town Opera]] of South Africa.
The 2015 festival included Mozart's ''[[The Magic Flute]]'', Verdi's ''[[Macbeth (opera)|Macbeth]]'', Vivaldi's ''[[Catone in Utica]]'', and Bernstein's ''[[Candide (operetta)|Candide]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://glimmerglass.org/festival/2015-mainstage/ |title=2015 Productions | The Glimmerglass Festival |publisher=Glimmerglass.org |date= |accessdate=2017-07-06}}</ref>
2016's season featured Puccini's ''[[La bohème]]'', Sondheim's ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street|Sweeney Todd]]'', Rossini's ''[[La gazza ladra]]'' (billed as ''The Thieving Magpie''), and Ward's ''[[The Crucible (opera)|The Crucible]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://glimmerglass.org/festival/2016-mainstage/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160326014410/https://glimmerglass.org/festival/2016-mainstage/ |archivedate=2016-03-26 |df= }}</ref>

{{About|the fraternity and sorority event|ethnic Greek events|Greek festival}} {{third-party|date=February 2014}} The '''Greek Picnic''' is an annual week-long event during the month of July in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]]. Originally designed as a reunion celebrating [[African American]] [[college]] [[fraternities]] and [[sororities]], it later gained popularity among a large population that do not attend college due to its various popular [[social]] activities. "Sister" events also include the Greek Festival in [[Hampton, Virginia]]; [[The Atlanta Greek Picnic]] in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]; The [[Charlotte Greek Picnic]] in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]; the [[Texas Greek Picnic]] in [[Houston]], [[Texas]], [[Nashville Greek Picnic]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], the California Greek Picnic in [[Los Angeles, California]] and [[Bikers Week]] in [[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina]].
==History== The Philadelphia Greek Picnic celebrated its 31st year on July 9, 2005 at the Belmont Grove in [[Fairmount Park]]. The Philadelphia Greek Picnic continues to be the nation’s oldest reunion for members of the historic nine African-American fraternities and sororities and people who appreciate and understand college and African American Greek-lettered life.
The Philadelphia Greek Picnic is co-sponsored by the City of Philadelphia, the Office of the Managing Director, the Fairmount Park Commission, the [[Philadelphia Police Department]] and the [[National Pan-Hellenic Council]] Inc. of Philadelphia. It is managed and coordinated by volunteers of the nine organizations wishing to make the entire week-long experience unforgettable based upon the themes of Scholarship, Fellowship and Respect.
==Popularity== During the early to mid 1990s the picnic grew national notoriety, attracting college students and party-goers from all over the east coast of the [[United States]]. The primary festival held in Fairmount Park frequently registered an attendance of 100,000+ people, with another 100,000-200,000 people scattered across the city in support of the events. Also various [[Hip hop music|hip-hop]] and [[R&B]] celebrities can be seen attending the events.
During the week the city receives a large economic boost due to [[tourism]]. Hotel and rental-car companies throughout Philadelphia, [[South Jersey]], and [[Delaware]] are reserved weeks to months in advance and opportunities for [[price gouging]] as the event grows closer are prevalent.
In recent years, the event has grown smaller, quieter and less troublesome to the police as well as attendants due to restructuring by the event organizers.
==Detractions== From the mid to late 1990s the Greek Picnic regressed into an event spoiled by frequent cases of assault, [[gun]]-related violence, [[car-jacking]], [[sexual harassment]], [[sexual assault]], and other crimes that seem to only happen at this specific event as opposed to other large gatherings within the city of Philadelphia.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}
Also during the event, [[traffic]] in the Philadelphia Area, particularly in [[West Philadelphia]] and [[South Street (Philadelphia)|South Street]] is at its most congested level for the year.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} The Philadelphia Police department often requires significant [[overtime]] of its officers for traffic control as well as crime deterrence.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}
==Events== The usual events during the week of the Greek Picnic are as follows:
*Day 0 Saturday- Books and [[Basketball]] Tournament, Acres of Diamonds *Day 1 Sunday- NPHC Worship Service, Cultural [[The arts|Arts]] Night *Day 3 Tuesday- Cultural Arts Night *Day 4 Wednesday- Stop the [[Violence]] Urban [[Dance]] Competition *Day 5 Thursday- Comedy Show *Day 6 Friday- President’s Reception *Day 7 Saturday- Stompfest Online’s National Stepshow, Fairmount Park Festival *Day 8 Sunday- Hair and Fashion Showcase
==See also== {{Portal|Philadelphia}} *[[Unity Day (Philadelphia)]]

'''HMCS ''Toronto'' (FFH 333)''' is a {{sclass-|Halifax|frigate|1}} that has served in the [[Canadian Forces]] since 1993. ''Toronto'' is the fourth ship in her class which is the name for the [[Canadian Patrol Frigate Project]]. She is the second vessel (and frigate) to carry the designation {{HMCS|Toronto}}. When not on operations she is assigned to [[Maritime Forces Atlantic]] (MARLANT) and is based at [[CFB Halifax]]. ''Toronto'' serves on MARLANT missions protecting Canada's sovereignty in the Atlantic Ocean and enforcing Canadian laws in its territorial sea and [[exclusive economic zone]].
==Description and design== The ''Halifax''-class frigate design of which ''Toronto'' belongs, was ordered by the [[Canadian Forces]] in 1977 as a replacement for the aging {{sclass-|St. Laurent|destroyer|5}}, {{sclass-|Restigouche|destroyer|5}}, {{sclass-|Mackenzie|destroyer|5}}, and {{sclass-|Annapolis|destroyer|4}}es of [[destroyer escort]]s , which were all tasked with [[anti-submarine warfare]].<ref name=milner284>Milner, p. 284</ref> In July 1983, the federal government approved the budget for the design and construction of the first batch of six new frigates of which ''Toronto'' was a part, out of twelve that were eventually built.<ref name=mac291>Macpherson and Barrie, p. 291</ref> To reflect the changing long term strategy of the Navy during the 1980s and 1990s, the ''Halifax''-class frigates was designed as a general purpose warship with particular focus on anti-submarine capabilities.<ref name=milner284/>
As built, the ''Halifax''-class vessels [[Displacement (ship)|displaced]] {{convert|4750|LT|t}} and were {{convert|441|ft|9|in|m|order=flip}} [[Length overall|long overall]] and {{convert|408|ft|5|in|m|order=flip}} [[Length between perpendiculars|between perpendiculars]] with a [[Beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|53|ft|8|in|m|order=flip}} and a [[Draft (hull)|draught]] of {{convert|16|ft|4|in|m|order=flip}}.<ref name=mac291/><ref name=saunders90>Saunders, p. 90</ref> That made them slightly larger than the ''Iroquois''-class destroyers.<ref name=mac291/> The vessels are propelled by two shafts with Escher Wyss controllable pitch [[propeller]]s driven by a [[CODOG]] system of two [[General Electric LM2500]] gas turbines, generating {{convert|47,500|shp|kW|lk=in}} and one [[SEMT Pielstick]] 20 PA6 V 280 [[diesel engine]], generating {{convert|8,800|shp|kW}}.<ref name=saunders90/>
This gives the frigates a maximum speed of {{convert|29|kn|lk=in}} and a range of {{convert|7000|nmi|lk=in}} at {{convert|15|kn}} while using their diesel engines.<ref name=mac291/><ref name=saunders90/> Using their gas turbines, the ships have a range of {{convert|3930|nmi}} at {{convert|18|kn}}. The ''Halifax'' class have a complement of 198 naval personnel of which 17 are officers and 17 aircrew of which 8 are officers.<ref name=saunders90/>
===Armament and aircraft=== As built the ''Halifax''-class vessels deployed the [[CH-124 Sea King]] helicopter, which acted in concert with shipboard sensors to seek out and destroy submarines at long distances from the ships. The ships have a helicopter deck fitted with a "[[Beartrap (helicopter device)|bear trap]]" system allowing the launch and recovery of helicopters in up to [[Sea State|sea state 6]]. The ''Halifax'' class also carries a close-in anti-submarine weapon in the form of the [[Mark 46 torpedo]], launched from twin Mark 32 Mod 9 torpedo tubes in launcher compartments either side of the forward end of the helicopter hangar.<ref name=saunders90/>
As built, the anti-shipping role is supported by the [[RGM-84 Harpoon]] Block 1C [[surface-to-surface missile]], mounted in two quadruple launch tubes at the main deck level between the funnel and the helicopter hangar.<ref name=mac291/><ref name=saunders90/> For [[anti-aircraft]] self-defence the ships are armed with the [[Sea Sparrow]] [[Vertical Launching System|vertical launch]] [[surface-to-air missile]] in two Mk 48 Mod 0 eight-cell launchers placed to port and starboard of the funnel. The vessels carry 16 missiles.<ref name=saunders90/> A [[Raytheon]]/[[General Dynamics]] [[Phalanx CIWS|Phalanx]] Mark 15 Mod 21 Close-In Weapon System (CIWS) is mounted on top of the helicopter hangar for "last-ditch" defence against targets that evade the Sea Sparrow.<ref name=saunders90/>
As built, the main gun on the [[forecastle]] is a [[Bofors 57 mm L/70 naval artillery gun|{{convert|57|mm|in|abbr=on|1}}/70 calibre Mark 2 gun]] from [[Bofors]].{{efn|name=gun nomenclature}} The gun is capable of firing {{convert|2.4|kg|adj=on}} shells at a rate of 220 rounds per minute at a range of more than {{convert|17|km}}.<ref name=saunders90/>
===Countermeasures and sensors=== As built, the decoy system comprises Two [[BAE Systems]] Shield Mark 2 decoy launchers which fire [[Chaff (radar countermeasure)|chaff]] to {{convert|2|km}} and infrared rockets to {{convert|169|m|yd}} in distraction, confusion and centroid seduction modes. The torpedo decoy is the [[SLQ-25 Nixie|AN/SLQ-25A Nixie]] towed acoustic decoy from Argon ST. The ship's radar warning receiver, the CANEWS (Canadian Electronic Warfare System), SLQ-501, and the radar jammer, SLQ-505, were developed by Thorn and Lockheed Martin Canada.<ref name=saunders90/>
Two [[Thales Nederland]] (formerly Signaal) SPG-503 (STIR 1.8) fire control radars are installed one on the roof of the bridge and one on the raised radar platform immediately forward of the helicopter hangar. The ship is also fitted with Raytheon [[AN/SPS-49]](V)5 long-range active air search radar operating at C and D bands, Ericsson HC150 Sea Giraffe medium-range air and surface search radar operating at G and H bands, and Kelvin Hughes Type 1007 I-band navigation radar. The sonar suite includes the CANTASS Canadian Towed Array and GD-C AN/SQS-510 hull mounted sonar and incorporates an acoustic range prediction system. The sonobuoy processing system is the GD-C AN/UYS-503.<ref name=saunders90/>
===Modernization=== The ''Halifax'' class underwent a modernization program, known as the Halifax Class Modernization (HCM) program, in order to update the frigates' capabilities in combatting modern smaller, faster and more mobile threats. This involved upgrading the command and control, radar, communications, electronic warfare and armament systems. Further improvements, such as modifying the vessel to accommodate the new [[Sikorsky CH-148 Cyclone]] helicopter and satellite links will be done separately from the main Frigate Equipment Life Extension (FELEX) program.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/business-equipment/halifax-frigate.page |title=Halifax-class Modernization / Frigate Life Extension |publisher=National Defence and the Canadian Armed Forces |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180217141250/http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/business-equipment/halifax-frigate.page |archivedate=17 February 2018 |accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
The FELEX program comprised upgrading the combat systems integration to CMS330. The SPS-49 2D long-range air search radar was replaced by the [[Thales Nederland]] SMART-S Mk 2 E/F-band 3D surveillance radar, and the two STIR 1.8 fire-control radars were replaced by a pair of Saab Ceros 200 recontrol radars. A Telephonics IFF Mode 5/S interrogator was installed and the Elisra NS9003A-V2HC ESM system replaced the SLQ-501 CANEWS. An IBM multi-link (Link 11, Link 16 and Link 22 enabled) datalink processing system was installed along with two [[Raytheon]] Anschütz Pathfinder Mk II navigation radars. Furthermore, [[Rheinmetall]]'s [[Multi Ammunition Softkill System]] (MASS), known as MASS DUERAS, was introduced to replace the Plessey Shield decoy system. The existing 57 mm Mk 2 guns were upgraded to the Mk 3 standard, the Harpoon missiles were improved to Block II levels, the Phalanx was upgraded to Block 1B, and the obsolete Sea Sparrow system was replaced by the [[Evolved Sea Sparrow Missile]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.janes.com/article/60726/halifax-class-upgrade-on-finals-cansec2016d2 |title=Halifax class upgrade on finals [CANSEC2016D2] |last=Scott |first=Richard |website=janes.com |date=26 May 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180217141122/http://www.janes.com/article/60726/halifax-class-upgrade-on-finals-cansec2016d2 |archivedate=17 February 2018 |accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
==Service history== ''Toronto'' was [[Keel laying|laid down]] on 22 April 1989 by [[Saint John Shipbuilding|Saint John Shipbuilding Ltd.]] at [[Saint John, New Brunswick]] and [[Ship naming and launching|launched]] on 18 December 1990. The frigate was [[Ship commissioning|commissioned]] into the Canadian Forces on 29 July 1993 at [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] and carries the [[hull classification symbol (Canada)|hull classification symbol]] FFH 333.<ref name=mac295>Macpherson and Barrie, p. 295</ref>
In 1994, ''Toronto'' deployed to the Adriatic Sea in support of the [[NATO]] blockade of [[Yugoslavia]]. In 1995, with {{HMCS|Halifax|FFH 330|2}} and {{HMCS|Terra Nova|DDE 259|2}}, ''Toronto'' sailed to Europe making a series of port visits in commemoration of the end of the [[Second World War]] in Europe. The same year, the ship took part in the NATO naval exercise Linked Seas off Portugal. In 1996, ''Toronto'' sailed through the [[St. Lawrence Seaway]] and the [[Great Lakes]] making several port visits.<ref name=mac295/>
In 1998, ''Toronto'' joined the NATO fleet [[STANAVFORLANT]] in January. On 10 February, the ship was redeployed to the [[Persian Gulf]] to assist in the enforcement of sanctions against Iraq.<ref name=mac295/> During the ship's deployment, the frigate served with a [[United States Navy]] fleet.<ref>Tracy, p. 204</ref><ref>Milner, p. 310</ref> The ship returned to Canada on 16 June. On 5 December, ''Toronto'' sailed to the [[Middle East]] as part of [[Operation Apollo]] in the [[War in Afghanistan (2001-2014)|War in Afghanistan]]. The ship returned to Canada on 27 May 2002.<ref name=mac295/> From January to July 2004, ''Toronto'' took part in Operation Altair, operating with the {{USS|George Washington|CVN-73|6}} Carrier Strike Group as part of a U.S.-led coalition in [[Operation Enduring Freedom]]. In summer 2005, ''Toronto'' performed another tour of the Great Lakes.<ref>Milner, p. 327</ref>
On 6 September 2005, ''Toronto'', with {{HMCS|Athabaskan|DDG 282|2}}, {{HMCS|St. John's|FFH 340|2}} and the [[Canadian Coast Guard]] vessel {{ship|CCGS|Sir William Alexander||2}}, were dispatched to the Gulf of Mexico to aid the United States in their response to the flooding of [[New Orleans]] by [[Hurricane Katrina]].<ref>Tracy, p. 282</ref> In 2008, ''Toronto'' with {{HMCS|Shawinigan|MM 704|2}} and the Canadian Coast Guard vessel {{ship|CCGS|Pierre Radisson||2}} made an Arctic patrol through [[Frobisher Bay]] as part of [[Operation Nanook (2009)|Operation Nanook]].<ref>Tracy, p. 294</ref> In 2009, ''Toronto'' deployed to the [[Caribbean Sea]] to perform drug-smuggling interdiction duties as part of [[Operation Caribbe]].<ref>Tracy, p. 285</ref> The ship returned to the Caribbean in 2011 as part of Operation Caribbe.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/operations-canada-north-america-recurring/op-caribbe.page |title=Operation Caribbe |publisher=National Defence and the Canadian Armed Forces |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180217154540/http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/operations-canada-north-america-recurring/op-caribbe.page |archivedate=17 February 2018 |accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
''Toronto'' participated in Operation Artemis, commencing her first rotation (ROTO 2) in January 2013 and finishing in February 2014 (which included a crew swap in July 2013 [the first crew swap in RCN history since 1991]).{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}
While relieving {{HMCS|Regina|FFH 334|2}} in the [[Mediterranean Sea]] as part of [[Standing NATO Maritime Group 2]], ''Toronto'' was reassigned to the [[Black Sea]] for Operation Reassurance in response to Russian intervention in Central and Eastern Europe. ''Toronto'' led Task Unit 2 (TU.02) and worked in concert with [[Spanish Navy]] frigate {{ship|Spanish frigate|Almirante Juan de Borbón|F102|2}}, and operated with [[Romanian Naval Forces|Romanian Navy]] frigate ''[[HMS Coventry (F98)|Regele Ferdinand]]'' and United States Navy destroyer {{USS|Ross|DDG-71|6}} as well as other vessels from Bulgaria, [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], Turkey, and Ukraine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.navy-marine.forces.gc.ca/en/news-operations/news-view.page?doc=hmcs-toronto-will-operate-in-the-black-sea-during-operation-reassurance/hyyl414u |title=HMCS Toronto will operate in the Black Sea during Operation Reassurance |work=Royal Canadian Navy |publisher=Government of Canada |date=5 September 2014 |accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
On 8 September 2014, ''Toronto'' was circled by two Russian [[Su-24]] attack aircraft and a Russian surveillance plane in a provocative manner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/russian-military-plane-circles-hmcs-toronto-in-black-sea-1.2759843 |title=Russian military planes buzzed HMCS Toronto in Black Sea |work=CBC News |date=8 September 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180217155109/http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/russian-military-planes-buzzed-hmcs-toronto-in-black-sea-1.2759843 |archivedate=17 February 2018 |accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref> In November 2014, six members of the crew helped fight a fire while on shore leave in Antalya, Turkey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/11/16/hmcs-toronto-crew-members-put-out-fire-in-turkey-after-spotting-burning-building-while-dining-on-shore/ |title=HMCS Toronto crew members put out fire in Turkey after spotting burning building while dining on shore |work=National Post |date=16 November 2014 |accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> While in the Mediterranean Sea, ''Toronto'' suffered a fire in its auxiliary machinery room on 25 December 2014. The fire was extinguished and all personnel affected by the smoke were treated and released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/metro/1259711-hmcs-toronto-deals-with-minor-on-board-fire-on-christmas-day |title=HMCS Toronto deals with minor on board fire on Christmas Day |last=Gorman |first=Michael |work=The Chronicle Herald |date=27 December 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180217154651/http://thechronicleherald.ca/metro/1259711-hmcs-toronto-deals-with-minor-on-board-fire-on-christmas-day |archivedate=17 February 2018 |accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref> During the frigate's deployment, ''Toronto'' participated in three naval exercises and led Task Unit 2 while operating in the Black Sea. {{HMCS|Fredericton|FFH 337|2}} relieved the ship in January 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/defence-watch/hmcs-fredericton-arrives-in-portugal-hmcs-toronto-to-be-back-in-canada-in-late-january |title=HMCS Fredericton arrives in Portugal, HMCS Toronto to be back in Canada in late January |last=Pugliese |first=David |work=Defence Watch |publisher=Ottawa Citizen|date=6 January 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180217154341/http://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/defence-watch/hmcs-fredericton-arrives-in-portugal-hmcs-toronto-to-be-back-in-canada-in-late-january |archivedate=17 February 2018 |accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
''Toronto'' was the last ship of the class to complete her FELEX refit, which was performed at Irving Shipyards in Halifax. The vessel was returned to the Royal Canadian Navy on 29 November 2016 to begin sea trials. The vessel was not expected to be operational until 2017–18.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/novascotia/1419770-irving-finishes-frigate-refits-for-navy |title=Irving finishes frigate refits for navy |last=Gunn |first=Andrea |newspaper=The Chronicle Herald |date=28 November 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180217154306/http://thechronicleherald.ca/novascotia/1419770-irving-finishes-frigate-refits-for-navy |archivedate=17 February 2018 |accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref> In January 2018, ''Toronto'' trained with the new Resolve-class auxiliary vessel, {{MV|Asterix}} off the coast of Nova Scotia.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/defence-watch/asterix-refuels-royal-canadian-navy-frigate-for-the-first-time |title=Asterix refuels Royal Canadian Navy frigate for the first time |work=Ottawa Citizen |last=Pugliese |first=David |date=16 January 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> In October, ''Toronto'' was deployed to European waters. During a series of exercises in UK waters, the frigate developed a significant electrical problem that caused a loss of power to the ship. Power was later restored and ''Toronto'' was ordered to [[Belfast]] for repairs.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/defence-watch/hmcs-toronto-headed-to-belfast-for-repairs-after-electrical-problems-cause-loss-of-power |title= HMCS Toronto headed to Belfast for repairs after electrical problems cause loss of power |work=Ottawa Citizen |last=Pugliese |first=David |date=30 October 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> As the frigate was docking in Belfast, a small fire began in the starboard gas turbine enclosure in the forward engine room, which was quickly extinguished by the crew. This marked the second such fire in days aboard ''Halifax''-class frigates, the first aboard {{HMCS|Halifax|FFH 330|2}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thechronicleherald.ca/news/canada/second-royal-canadian-navy-ship-hit-by-fire-while-deployed-off-europe-255331/ |title=Second Royal Canadian Navy ship hit by fire while deployed off Europe |agency=The Canadian Press |work=The Chronicle Herald |date=31 October 2018 |accessdate=3 November 2018}}</ref>
==Images== <gallery> File:HMCS Toronto (FFH 333) 1.jpg| File:HMCS Toronto (inset).jpg| File:US Navy 040214-N-5319A-003 Canadian Navy, Master Corporal Christopher Kelly photographs the crew of the Canadian Navy Halifax-class patrol frigate, HMCS Toronto (FFH 333) on Valentine^rsquo,s Day.jpg| File:HMCS Toronto (FFH 333) 4.jpg| File:HMCS Toronto (FFH 333).jpg| File:Ships of Standing NATO Maritime Group 1.jpg| </gallery>
==References== ===Notes=== {{notes | notes =
{{efn | name = gun nomenclature | The 70 [[Caliber (artillery)|calibre]] denotes the length of the gun. This means that the length of the gun barrel is 70 times the bore diameter. }} }}

{{Infobox television | show_name = Hillsborough | image = File:Hillsborough_film_title_screen.jpg | image_upright = 1.14 | image_alt = Hillsborough film title screen | genre = [[Docudrama]] | writer = [[Jimmy McGovern]] | director = [[Charles McDougall]] | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Annabelle Apsion]] * [[Joe Duttine]] * {{nowrap|[[Christopher Eccleston]]}} * [[Bruce Jones (actor)|Bruce Jones]] * [[Andrew Lancel]] * [[Maurice Roëves]] * [[Ricky Tomlinson]] * [[Stephen Walters]] * [[Tracey Wilkinson]] * [[Scot Williams]] * [[Mark Womack (British actor)|Mark Womack]] }} | theme_music_composer = Rob Lane | country = United Kingdom | language = English | executive_producer = {{plainlist| * Ian McBride * Gub Neal }} | producer = [[Nicola Shindler]] | cinematography = [[Barry Ackroyd]] | runtime = 101 minutes | company = [[ITV Granada|Granada Television]] | budget = £2 million | network = [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] | picture_format = [[PAL]] ([[576i]]) | audio_format = [[Stereophonic sound|Stereo]] | first_aired = {{Film date|TV=y|1996|12|05|df=yes}} }} '''''Hillsborough''''' is a [[television film]] written by [[Jimmy McGovern]] and starring [[Christopher Eccleston]] and [[Ricky Tomlinson]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/jun/10/features.features11|title=The power of truth|last=McGovern|first=Jimmy|date=2004-06-10|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-20}}</ref> Set between 1989 and 1991, the film is a dramatization of the [[Hillsborough disaster]], which saw 96 football supporters lose their lives at [[Hillsborough Stadium|Hillsborough]] in [[Sheffield]].
==Background== In April 1989, [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] met in the semi-finals of the [[1988–89 FA Cup|FA Cup]]. The match was played at [[Hillsborough Stadium]] in [[Sheffield]] but was abandoned shortly after the match had started when it became clear that the fans packed in to the [[Leppings Lane]] end of the ground were being crushed against fencing. 94 fans died that day, with a 95th victim dying a few days later, and the final death toll reaching 96 in 1993.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/28/world/europe/uk-hillsborough-soccer-stadium-charges.html|title=Six Are Charged in 1989 Hillsborough Stadium Disaster in England|last=Bilefsky|first=Dan|date=2017-06-28|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-11-17|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
==Production== In 1995, two women who had lost children in the disaster asked McGovern if he would write their story. He began by interviewing the families of the victims, and became so angry at the unfolding story that he brought in writer Katy Jones to verify that his writing was not skewed in any way.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/jun/10/features.features11|title=The power of truth|last=McGovern|first=Jimmy|date=2004-06-10|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-07-27}}</ref>
The film was produced by [[ITV Granada|Granada Television]] for [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] and aired for the first time on 5 December 1996.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/christopher-eccleston-says-jimmy-mcgoverns-3391835|title=Christopher Eccleston says Jimmy McGovern’s Hillsborough is most important work he's ever done|last=Shennan|first=Paddy|date=2010-11-30|work=liverpoolecho|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref> Since then, it has been repeated four times: 10 years after the disaster (15 April 1999), 20 years after the disaster (17 April 2009), on 14 September 2012 after the report by the [[Hillsborough disaster#Hillsborough Independent Panel|Hillsborough Independent Panel]] was published, and on 1 May 2016 after the conclusion of the [[Hillsborough disaster#Second coroner's hearing|second inquest]] which ruled that the 96 victims were unlawfully killed.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/jimmy-mcgoverns-hillsborough-documentary-broadcast-11266612|title=Jimmy McGovern's Hillsborough documentary to be broadcast this weekend|last=Fitzsimmons|first=Francesca|date=2016-04-30|work=liverpoolecho|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-19545126|title=How the Hillsborough disaster unfolded|date=2016-04-26|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-11-17|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Though filmed after the death of the final victim ([[Tony Bland]]) who died in March 1993, after being in a coma for nearly four years, the time setting of the film concluded in 1991 when the death toll stood at 95.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/hillsborough-tributes-tony-bland-3418448|title=Tony Bland, 22|last=Echo|first=Liverpool|date=2009-04-14|work=liverpoolecho|access-date=2018-06-20}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
==Cast== * [[Christopher Eccleston]] as Trevor Hicks * [[Annabelle Apsion]] as Jenni Hicks * Sarah Graham as Sarah Hicks * Anna Martland as Vicki Hicks * [[Ricky Tomlinson]] as John Glover * [[Rachel Davies]] as Teresa Glover * [[Scot Williams]] as Joe Glover * [[Stephen Walters]] as Ian Glover * [[Mark Womack (British actor)|Mark Womack]] as Eddie Spearritt * [[Tracey Wilkinson]] as Jan Spearritt * Kevin Knapman as Adam Spearritt * [[Ian McDiarmid]] as the Judge
==Reception== The film was generally well received by the public and television critics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv-review-hillsborough-itv-1313223.html|title=TV Review: Hillsborough (ITV)|date=1996-12-06|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-11-17|language=en-GB}}</ref> The [[Independent Television Commission]] praised Granada for the drama in its annual programme review, describing it as '' 'arguably the most powerful drama on the screen in 1996'.''<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Dream That Died: The Rise and Fall of ITV |first=Raymond |last=Fitzwalter |publisher=Troubador Publishing Ltd |year=2008 |isbn=1-906221-83-9 |page=286}}</ref> It won the [[British Academy Television Awards|BAFTA Television Award]] in [[British Academy Television Awards 1997|1997]] for Best Single Drama, Best Editing and Best Sound.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://awards.bafta.org/award/1997/television/single-drama|title=BAFTA Awards|website=awards.bafta.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://awards.bafta.org/award/1997/tvcraft|title=Television Craft in 1997 {{!}} BAFTA Awards|website=awards.bafta.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref> In 2000, the [[British Film Industry]] placed ''Hillsborough'' at number 54 in its list of the [[100 Greatest British Television Programmes]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110911083558/http://www.bfi.org.uk/features/tv/100/list/list.php|title=BFI {{!}} Features {{!}} TV 100 List of Lists|date=2011-09-11|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref>
==Home media== Five months after the twentieth anniversary of the tragedy, on 7 September 2009, the ''Hillsborough'' docu-drama was released on DVD.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.networkdvd.net/product_info.php?products_id=952 |title=Hillsborough |publisher=Network DVD |accessdate=7 May 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb title|0116533|Hillsborough}} [[Category:1996 television films]] [[Category:1999 television films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British drama films]] [[Category:British television films]] [[Category:Association football films]] [[Category:Films set in 1989]] [[Category:Hillsborough disaster]] [[Category:Television programmes produced by Granada Television]] [[Category:English-language television programs]]

The '''International Committee for Exhibition Exchange''' ('''ICEE''') is a committee of the [[International Council of Museums]] (ICOM). It is a nongovernmental organization with formal relations to the [[UNESCO]] and functions as a forum for the dissemination of knowledge and experience about exhibitions.
The committee deals with many different aspects of exhibition development, circulation, and exchange. It also collects information about potential as well as existing travelling exhibitions. The '''ICEE''' holds meetings annually and has publications that offer solutions to the problems of organizing exhibitions.
==See also== * [[Art exhibition]] * [[Art gallery]] * [[Curator]] * [[National Touring Exhibitions]] * [[Travelling exhibition]]
==References== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080922024824/http://www.ballodora.de/icee/ ICOM — International Committee for Exhibition Exchange] * [http://icom.museum/ International Council of Museums (ICOM)]
==External links== * [http://www.webartex.com/ International Exhibitions Marketplace], known as WebArtEx * [http://www.a-r-t.com/ Landau Travelling Exhibitions] in the United States * [http://www.sites.si.edu/ Smithsonian Institution Travelling Exhibition Service] in the United States * [http://www.riksutstallningar.se/Templates/StartPageEN____5.aspx Swedish Travelling Exhibitions], Swedish government organization * [http://www.teg.org.uk/ The Touring Exhibitions Group], U.K.-based organization * [http://www.touringexhibition.co.uk/ IDEAS Touring Exhibition], International - U.K. based [[Category:Museum events]] [[Category:Exhibitions]] [[Category:Museum associations and consortia]]

{{About|the ballroom dance style|other dances that go by the name "jive"|Jive (disambiguation){{!}}Jive}} [[File:Jive Suvorovs Bazokina 9348.JPG|thumb|Austrian Open Championships Vienna, 2012 WDSF World Dancesport Championships Latin 16.-18. November 2012 ]] [[File:New Style Dancing Arrives- the Introduction of the Jive Into British Dance Halls, 1945 D23830.jpg|thumb|Jiving in a British dance hall, 1945]] In [[latin dancing]], the '''jive''' is a [[dance]] style that originated in the United States from [[African-American]]s in the early 1930s. It was popularized in 1934 by [[Cab Calloway]]. It is a lively and uninhibited variation of the [[Jitterbug]], a form of [[Swing dance]]. [[Glenn Miller]] introduced his own jive dance in 1938 with the song "Doin' the Jive" which never caught on.
==Overview== The hand jive is one of the five [[Ballroom dancing|International Latin]] dances. In competition it is danced at a speed of 176 [[Tempo|beats per minute]], although in some cases this is reduced to between 128 and 160 beats per minute.
Many of its basic patterns are similar to these of the [[East Coast Swing]] with the major difference of highly [[syncopation (dance)|syncopated]] rhythm of the [[Triple Step]]s ([[Chasse]]s), which use [[straight eighths]] in ECS and [[hard swing]] in Jive. To the players of swing music in the 1930s and 1940s "Jive" was an expression denoting glib or foolish talk.<ref>Early Jazz: Its Roots and Musical Development. by Gunther Schuller. 1968. Oxford University Press. page 379. {{ISBN|0-19-504043-0}}</ref>
American soldiers brought [[Lindy Hop]]/[[Jitterbug]] to Europe around 1940, where this dance swiftly found a following among the young. In the United States the term Swing became the most common word used to describe the dance, and the term "jive" was adopted in the UK. Variations in technique led to styles such as boogie-woogie and swing boogie, with "jive" gradually emerging as the generic term in the UK.<ref>Paul Bottomer. 1997. Black Dog & Leventhal. page 157. {{ISBN|1-57912-049-0}}</ref>
After the war, the [[boogie]] became the dominant form for popular music. It was, however, never far from criticism as a foreign, vulgar dance. The famous ballroom dancing guru, [[Alex Moore (dancer)|Alex Moore]], said that he had "never seen anything uglier". In 1968 it was adopted as the fifth Latin dance in International competitions. The modern form of ballroom jive in the 1990s–present, is a very happy and boppy dance, the lifting of knees and the bending or rocking of the hips often occurs.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscat|Jive}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rxvQ6yNGIes Jive performance video] * [http://www.jivetreasurebox.com The Jive Treasure Box - A comprehensive database of Modern Jive moves illustrated].
{{Dance}} {{Authority control}}
[[Category:Ballroom dance]] [[Category:Latin dances]]<!-- International Style --> [[Category:Swing dances]]

{{italic title}} [[Image:Kattenstoet.jpg|thumb|''Minneke Poes'', one of the giant cats in the ''Kattenstoet'']]
The '''''Kattenstoet''''' (lit. "Festival of the Cats") is a parade in [[Ypres]], Belgium, devoted to the [[cat]]. It has been held regularly on the second Sunday of May since 1955.<ref name="allred">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Muvn6KZR-xsC&pg=PA234&dq=kattenstoet&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KBvhUYu2JMfQhAeGnIGICw&ved=0CDYQuwUwAA#v=onepage&q=kattenstoet&f=false|title=Cats' Most Wanted: The Top 10 Book Of Mysterious Mousers, Talented Tabbies And Feline Oddities|author=Alexandra Powe Allred|publisher=Potomac Books|year=2005|page=234|isbn= 9781574888584}}</ref> Most recently, the 44th edition took place on May 10, 2015,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Streams|first1=Kimber|title=Kattenstoet, A Cat Parade Held Every Three Years in Ypres, Belgium|url=http://laughingsquid.com/kattenstoet-a-cat-parade-held-every-three-years-in-ypres-belgium/|website=Laughing Squid|publisher=Laughing Squid LLC|accessdate=23 November 2015}}</ref> with the 45th expecting to take place on May 13, 2018.<ref name="official">{{cite web|url=http://www.kattenstoet.be/en/home.html|title=Kattenstoet (official site)|publisher=Vredesstad Ieper (Ypres town council)|accessdate=23 November 2015}}</ref> The parade commemorates an Ypres tradition from the [[Middle Ages]] in which cats were thrown from the [[bell tower|belfry]] tower of the [[Cloth Hall, Ypres|Cloth Hall]] to the town square below.
==Background== There are various legends about how the throwing of cats originated. One possibility is that cats were connected to [[witchcraft]], and the throwing of the cats symbolised the killing of evil spirits.<ref name="frommer">{{cite book |title=Frommer's Belgium, Holland & Luxembourg |author=George McDonald |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=49GG3_8xV4EC&lpg=PA203&ots=Z8B_5ElMC4&pg=PA203#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-0-470-38227-1 |publisher=Frommer's |page=203}}</ref> The last recorded event of this kind was in 1817.<ref name="allred"/> Another story suggests that the cats were brought into the [[Cloth Hall, Ypres|Cloth Hall]] (''Lakenhallen'') to control vermin. Before modern heating and storage methods, when it got cold the wool was stored in the upper floors of the Cloth Hall. At the start of the spring warm-up, after the wool had been sold, the cats were tossed out of the [[bell tower]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ethesis.net/ieper_kattenfeesten/ieper_kattenfeesten.htm |title=De Kattenfeesten te Ieper. Een analyse van de Kattenstoet en het Kattenwerpen aan de hand van de theorie van Hobsbawm. |language=Dutch |accessdate=2011-03-28}}</ref>
==Modern festival== [[File:Kattenstoet after ww2.jpg|thumb|upright|Kattenstoet in the 1950s]]
Symbolically reviving this practice for the parade festivities, a jester tosses plush children's-toy cats from the Cloth Hall belfry down to the crowd, which awaits with outstretched arms to catch one. The throwing of the cats from the belfry is followed by a mock [[witch hunt|witch burning]]. Participants in the festivities often dress as cats, witches, mice, or townspeople from ages past, and the festival also features brass bands and people riding on horseback. Around 2,000 people participated in the 2012 parade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cheapflights.co.uk/news/love-cats-us-too-kattenstoet-festival-of-cats/|title=Love cats? We do too|author=Brett Ackroyd|publisher=Cheap Flights|date=12 May 2012|accessdate=13 July 2013}}</ref> The festival is a popular tourist event in Belgium and has helped strengthen the local tourist economy around Ypres. 8,000 people visited the event in 2000.<ref name="allred"/>
==See also== *[[Cat burning]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons}} * [http://www.kattenstoet.be/ Official Kattenstoet festival Website] - City of Ieper
[[Category:Cats in popular culture]] [[Category:Parades in Belgium]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in West Flanders]] [[Category:Ypres]] [[Category:Belgian folklore]] [[Category:Spring (season) events in Belgium]] [[Category:Triennial events]]

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
[[File:Farewell address Robert E Lee.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The Farewell Address of [[General (CSA)|General]] [[Robert E. Lee]] known as General Order No. 9 to his [[Confederate States Army]], the [[Army of Northern Virginia]] on April 10, 1865, from an 1883 Library of Congress reprint]] [[File:General Robert Edward Lee's farewell to his soldiers.jpg|thumb|right|250px|General Lee's farewell to his soldiers as depicted by Henry D. Northrop]] [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] [[General (CSA)|General]] [[Robert E. Lee]] issued his '''Farewell Address''', also known as '''General Order No. 9''' (sometimes '''Orders''') to his [[Army of Northern Virginia]] on April 10, 1865, the day after he surrendered the army to [[Lieutenant general (United States)|Lt. Gen.]] [[Ulysses S. Grant]]. Lee's surrender was instrumental in bringing about the end of the [[American Civil War]]. The text of the order, which were written and drafted by Col. [[Charles Marshall (colonel)|Charles Marshall]], edited and finalized by Lee, were issued as follows:{{cite web|url=http://www.virginialiving.com/an-honorable-peace/|title=An Honorable Peace|last1=Larson|first1=Chiles T.A.|date=March 25, 2015|website=[[Virginia Living]] |publisher=Cape Fear Publishing|access-date=June 27, 2016 |quote=}} {{quote|Headquarters, Army of Northern Virginia, 10th April 1865.

General Order No. 9 After four years of arduous service marked by unsurpassed courage and fortitude, the Army of Northern Virginia has been compelled to yield to overwhelming numbers and resources. I need not tell the survivors of so many hard fought battles, who have remained steadfast to the last, that I have consented to the result from no distrust of them. But feeling that valour and devotion could accomplish nothing that could compensate for the loss that must have attended the continuance of the contest, I have determined to avoid the useless sacrifice of those whose past services have endeared them to their countrymen. By the terms of the agreement, officers and men can return to their homes and remain until exchanged. You will take with you the satisfaction that proceeds from the consciousness of duty faithfully performed, and I earnestly pray that a merciful God will extend to you his blessing and protection. With an unceasing admiration of your constancy and devotion to your Country, and a grateful remembrance of your kind and generous consideration for myself, I bid you an affectionate farewell.|R. E. Lee, General|General Order No. 9Freeman, vol. 4, pp. 154-55.}} The following is taken from a letter dated September 27, 1887, to General [[Bradley Tyler Johnson|Bradley T. Johnson]] from Colonel [[Charles Marshall (Colonel)|Charles Marshall]], CSA.Johnson, Buel, vol. 4, p. 747. {{quote|General Lee's order to the Army of Northern Virginia at Appomattox Court House was written the day after the meeting at McLean's house, at which the terms of the surrender were agreed upon. That night the general sat with several of us at a fire in front of his tent, and after some conversation about the army, and the events of the day, in which his feelings toward his men were strongly expressed, he told me to prepare an order to the troops. The next day it was raining, and many persons were coming and going, so that I was unable to write without interruption until about 10 o'clock, when General Lee, finding that the order had not been prepared, directed me to get into his ambulance, which stood near his tent, and placed an orderly to prevent any one from approaching me. I sat in the ambulance until I had written the order, the first draft of which (in pencil) contained an entire paragraph that was omitted by General Lee's direction. He made one or two verbal changes, and I then made a copy of the order as corrected, and gave it to one of the clerks in the adjutant-general's office to write in ink. I took the copy, when made by the clerk, to the general, who signed it, and other copies were then made for transmission to the corps commanders and the staff of the army. All these copies were signed by the general, and a good many persons sent other copies which they had made or procured, and obtained his signature. In this way many copies of the order had the general's name signed as if they were originals, some of which I have seen.}} ==See also== *[[Robert E. Lee]] *[[Battle of Appomattox Court House]] *[[McLean House (Appomattox, Virginia)]] {{wikisource|Robert E. Lee's letter announcing surrender}} ==References== * [[Douglas S. Freeman|Freeman, Douglas S.]], [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/People/Robert_E_Lee/FREREL/home.html ''R. E. Lee, A Biography''] (4 volumes), Scribners, 1934. * [[Robert Underwood Johnson|Johnson, Robert Underwood]], and Buel, Clarence C. (eds.), [http://ehistory.osu.edu/osu/books/battles/index.cfm ''Battles and Leaders of the Civil War''], Century Co., 1884-1888. ==Notes== {{reflist}} [[Category:American Civil War documents]] [[Category:Farewell addresses]] [[Category:United States historical documents]] [[Category:1865 documents]] [[Category:General orders]] [[Category:April 1865 events]] [[Category:Robert E. Lee]]

{{Redirect|Royal wedding|the 1951 MGM musical|Royal Wedding}} {{Unreferenced|date=October 2018}} [[File:The marriage procession of Dara Shikoh - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|The [[Mughal emperors|Mughal Emperor]] [[Shah Jahan]] attends the marriage procession of his eldest son [[Dara Shikoh]]. Mughal-Era [[fireworks]] were utilized to brighten the night throughout the wedding ceremony.]]
A '''royal wedding''' is a [[marriage ceremony]] involving members of a [[royal family]]. Weddings involving senior members of the royal family are often seen as important occasions of state and attract significant national and international attention. The following is a list of notable royal weddings:
== 19th century == ===Russian Empire=== * [[Wedding of Nicholas II and Alexandra Feodorovna|26 November 1895]]: [[Nicholas II of Russia|Nicholas II]], the last [[Emperor of All Russia|Emperor of Russia]], was married to [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)|Alexandra Feodorovna]] at the [[Grand Church of the Winter Palace]].
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha|10 February 1840]]: [[Queen Victoria]], only daughter of [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn]], and successor of [[William IV of the United Kingdom|King William IV]], was married to [[Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]], Duke of Saxony, at the [[Chapel Royal]], [[St James's Palace]]. * [[Wedding of Prince George, Duke of York, and Princess Mary of Teck|6 July 1893]]: [[George V|Prince George, Duke of York]], second son of King [[Edward VII]], was married to [[Mary of Teck|Princess Victoria Mary of Teck]] at the [[Chapel Royal]], [[St James's Palace]].
== 20th century == ===Belgium=== * [[Wedding of Prince Philippe and Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz|4 December 1999]]: [[Philippe of Belgium|Prince Philippe, Duke of Brabant]], eldest child and successor to [[Albert II of Belgium|King Albert II]], was married to [[Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz]] at the [[Cathedral of St. Michael and St. Gudula]].
===Greece=== * [[Wedding of Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece, and Marie-Chantal Miller|1 July 1995]]: [[Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece]], eldest son and second child of [[Constantine II of Greece|King Constantine II]], was married to [[Marie-Chantal, Crown Princess of Greece|Marie-Chantal Miller]].
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Prince Albert, Duke of York, and Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|26 April 1923]]: [[George VI|Prince Albert, Duke of York]], second son of King [[George V]] and successor to [[Edward VIII|King Edward VIII]], was married to [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother|Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Philip Mountbatten|20 November 1947]]: [[Elizabeth II|Princess Elizabeth]], eldest daughter and successor of King [[George VI]], was married to [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Anne and Mark Phillips|14 November 1973]]: [[Anne, Princess Royal|Princess Anne]], only daughter of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Mark Phillips|Captain Mark Phillips]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer|29 July 1981]]: [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], eldest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Lady Diana Spencer]] at [[St Paul's Cathedral]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson|23 July 1986]]: [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]], second son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Sarah, Duchess of York|Sarah Ferguson]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones|19 June 1999]]: [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]], youngest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex|Sophie Rhys-Jones]] at [[St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle]].
== 21st century == ===Bhutan=== * [[Wedding of Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck and Jetsun Pema|13 October 2011]]: [[Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck]], King of Bhutan, was married to [[Jetsun Pema]] at the [[Punakha Dzong]] in [[Punakha|Punakha, Bhutan]].
===Denmark=== * [[Wedding of Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark, and Mary Donaldson|14 May 2004]]: [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark|Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark]], eldest son of [[Margrethe II of Denmark]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Mary, Crown Princess of Denmark|Mary Elizabeth Donaldson]] at the [[Church of Our Lady (Copenhagen)|Church of Our Lady]], [[Copenhagen]].
===Luxembourg=== * [[Wedding of Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg, and Countess Stéphanie de Lannoy|20 October 2012]]: [[Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Hereditary Grand Duke Guillaume]], eldest son of [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Stéphanie, Hereditary Grand Duchess of Luxembourg|Countess Stephanie de Lannoy]] at the [[Notre-Dame Cathedral, Luxembourg]].
===Monaco=== * [[Wedding of Albert II, Prince of Monaco, and Charlene Wittstock|1 July 2011]]: [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|Albert II]], [[Monarchy of Monaco|Sovereign Prince]] of Monaco, was married to [[Charlene, Princess of Monaco|Charlene Lynette Wittstock]] at the [[Prince's Palace of Monaco]].
===Norway=== * [[Wedding of Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway, and Mette-Marit Tjessem Høiby|25 August 2001]]: [[Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway|Crown Prince Haakon of Norway]], only son of King [[Harald V of Norway]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Mette-Marit, Crown Princess of Norway|Mette-Marit Tjessem Høiby]] at the [[Oslo Cathedral]].
===Spain=== * [[Wedding of Prince Felipe and Letizia Ortiz|22 May 2004]]: [[Felipe VI of Spain|Prince Felipe of Asturias]], only son of [[Juan Carlos I of Spain]], was married to [[Queen Letizia of Spain|Letizia Ortiz]] at the [[Almudena Cathedral]] at [[Royal Palace of Madrid]], [[Madrid]].
===Sweden=== * [[Wedding of Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden, and Daniel Westling|19 June 2010]]: [[Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden|Crown Princess Victoria of Sweden]], eldest daughter and heir apparent of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Prince Daniel, Duke of Västergötland|Daniel Westling]] at the [[Stockholm Cathedral]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Madeleine and Christopher O'Neill|8 June 2013]]: [[Princess Madeleine, Duchess of Hälsingland and Gästrikland|Princess Madeleine of Sweden]], youngest child of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Christopher O'Neill]] at the [[Stockholm Palace]] Church. * [[Wedding of Prince Carl Philip and Sofia Hellqvist|13 June 2015]]: [[Prince Carl Philip, Duke of Värmland|Prince Carl Philip]], Only son of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Sofia Hellqvist]] at the [[Stockholm Palace]] Church.
===Tonga=== * [[Wedding of Crown Prince Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala and Sinaitakala Fakafanua|12 July 2012]]: [[Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala]], Crown Prince of Tonga, was married to [[Sinaitakala Fakafanua]] at the Centennial Church in [[Nukuʻalofa]], Tonga.
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles|9 April 2005]]: [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], eldest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall|Camilla Parker Bowles]] at [[Windsor Guildhall]]. * [[Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton|29 April 2011]]: [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]], second grandson of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], elder son of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and [[Lady Diana Spencer]] is second in line to the throne, was married to [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Catherine Middleton]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle|19 May 2018]]: [[Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex]], third grandson of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], younger son of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and [[Lady Diana Spencer]] is sixth in line to the throne, was married to [[Meghan, Duchess of Sussex|Meghan Markle]] at [[St George's Chapel]], [[Windsor Castle]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank|12 October 2018]]: [[Princess Eugenie]], third granddaughter of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], younger daughter of [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]] and [[Sarah Ferguson]] is ninth in line to the throne, was married to [[Jack Brooksbank]] at [[St George's Chapel]], [[Windsor Castle]].

{{Yearsinfilm}} <!-- Please DO NOT ADD anything to this list until AFTER it has been added to the relevant year in film itself. SGBailey -- --> This '''list of years in film''' indexes the individual ''year in film'' pages. Each year is annotated with the significant events as a reference point. __NOTOC__ * [[#19th century in film|19th century in film]] * 20th century in film: ** [[#1900s|1900s]] – [[#1910s|1910s]] – [[#1920s|1920s]] – [[#1930s|1930s]] – [[#1940s|1940s]] – [[#1950s|1950s]] – [[#1960s|1960s]] – [[#1970s|1970s]] – [[#1980s|1980s]] – [[#1990s|1990s]] * 21st century in film: ** [[#2000s|2000s]] – [[#2010s|2010s]] – [[#2020s|2020s]]
==19th century in film== {{See also|19th century in film}} * '''[[1886 in film|1886]]''' – [[Louis Aimé Augustin Le Prince]] is granted an American dual-patent on a 16-lens device that combined a motion picture camera with a projector. * '''[[1888 in film|1888]]''' – The ''[[Roundhay Garden Scene]]'', shot in [[Leeds]], [[West Yorkshire]], England by [[Louis Aimé Augustin Le Prince|Le Prince]], is credited as the first film. It is recorded at a groundbreaking 20 [[film frame|frames]] per second and is the earliest surviving film. [[Thomas Edison]] describes the concept of the [[Kinetoscope]], an early motion picture exhibition device. * '''[[1889 in film|1889]]''' – [[Eastman Kodak]] is the first company to begin commercial production of film on a flexible transparent base, [[celluloid]]. The first moving pictures developed on celluloid film are made in [[Hyde Park, London]] by [[William Friese Greene]]. * '''[[1890 in film|1890]]''' – [[William Kennedy Dickson]] completes his work for [[Thomas Edison]] on the Kinetograph cylinder either in this year or 1889. ''[[Monkeyshines No. 1]]'' becomes the first film shot on the system. * '''[[1891 in film|1891]]''' – [[Thomas Edison]] files for a patent of the [[motion picture camera]]. Edison holds the first public presentation of his Kinetoscope for the National Federation of Women's Clubs. * '''[[1892 in film|1892]]''' – The Kinetoscope is completed by [[William Kennedy Dickson]], at the employ of [[Thomas Edison]]. In France, [[Charles-Émile Reynaud]] begins to have public screenings in Paris at the [[Théâtre Optique]], with hundreds of drawings on a reel that he wound through his Projecting Praxinoscope, similar to the Zoetrope, to construct moving images that continued for 15 minutes. The [[Eastman Company]] becomes the [[Eastman Kodak Company]]. [[Max Skladanowsky]] develops a camera and shoots his first footage this year, but its unusual interleaved image format leaves him ultimately unable to exhibit it until work is completed on the Bioskop projector in late 1895. * '''[[1893 in film|1893]]''' – [[Thomas Edison]] is granted Patent #493,426 for "An Apparatus for Exhibiting Photographs of Moving Objects" (the [[Kinetoscope]]). Edison builds "America's First Movie Studio", the [[Edison's Black Maria|Black Maria]], in [[West Orange, New Jersey]]. The premiere of the completed Kinetoscope is held on May 9 at the [[Brooklyn Museum|Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences]]. The first film publicly shown on the system was ''[[Blacksmith Scene]]'' (aka Blacksmiths). * '''[[1894 in film|1894]]''' – [[William Kennedy Dickson]] receives a patent for [[film|motion picture film]]. [[Thomas Edison]] records [[Fred Ott]]'s [[Fred Ott's Sneeze|sneeze]]. [[Auguste and Louis Lumière]] patent the [[Cinématographe]], a combination movie camera and projector. * '''[[1895 in film|1895]]''' – The [[cinématographe]] is patented. First footage ever to be shot using it is recorded on March 19. [[Auguste and Louis Lumière|The Lumière brothers]] hold their first private screening of projected motion pictures on March 22. The Lumières give the first public screening at L'Eden, the world's first and oldest cinéma ([[Movie theater|theater]]), located in [[La Ciotat]], France, on September 28. [[Gaumont Film Company|Gaumont Pictures]] is founded by the engineer-turned-inventor, [[Léon Gaumont]]. In the US, the [[The Dickson Experimental Sound Film|Dickson Experimental Sound Film]] presents two men dancing to the sound of a violin player, in what the documentary film ''[[The Celluloid Closet]]'' calls the first gay cinema reference. The first screening of movies at which admission was charged takes place on December 28, in Paris, at the Salon Indien du Grand Café. This historical screening is based on ten short films, in the following order (and respective length): ''[[Workers Leaving the Lumière Factory|Sortie de l'usine Lumière à Lyon]]'' (Workers Leaving the Lumière Factory), 46 seconds; ''La Voltige'' ("Horse Trick Riders"), 46 seconds: ''La Pêche aux Poissons Rouges'' ("Fishing for Goldfish"), 42 seconds; ''Le Débarquement du Congrès de Photographie à Lyon'' ("The Disembarkment of the Congress of Photographers in Lyon"), 48 seconds; ''Les Forgerons'' ("Blacksmiths"), 49 seconds; ''Le Jardinier ([[l'Arroseur Arrosé]])'' ("The Gardener, [The Sprinkler Sprinkled]"), 49 seconds; ''Le Repas (de Bébé)'' ("Baby's Meal"), 41 seconds; ''Le Saut à la Couverture'' ("Jumping Onto the Blanket"), 41 seconds; ''La Place des Cordeliers à Lyon'' ("Cordeliers Square in Lyon – a Street Scene"), 44 seconds; ''La Mer (Baignade en Mer)'' ("The Sea [Bathing in the Sea]"), 38 seconds. In Germany, [[Emil Skladanowsky|Emil]] and [[Max Skladanowsky]] develop their own film projector – they project from November 1 in Berlin. The [[American Mutoscope and Biograph Company]] motion pictures was founded in New Jersey by the KMCD Syndicate of [[William Kennedy Dickson]], [[Henry Marvin]], [[Herman Casler]] and [[Elias Koopman]]. [[Woodville Latham]] and his sons develop the Latham Loop – the concept of loose loops of film on either side of the [[intermittent mechanism|intermittent movement]] to prevent stress from the jerky movement. This is debuted in the [[Eidoloscope]], which is also the first widescreen format (1.85:1). [[Herman Casler]] of American Mutoscope Company, aka [[American Mutoscope and Biograph Company]] manufactures the Biograph 68 mm camera, which will become the first successful large format 68 mm (70 mm) film. * '''[[1896 in film|1896]]''' – [[Pathé Frères]] is founded. In Britain, [[Birt Acres]] and [[Robert W. Paul]] developed their own film projector, the [[Theatrograph]] (later known as the [[Animatograph]]). [[Georges Méliès]] buys an English projector from [[Robert William Paul]] and shoots his first films. A projector called the [[Vitascope]] is designed by [[Charles Francis Jenkins]]. The first [[Movie theater|theater]] in the US dedicated exclusively to showing motion pictures is [[Vitascope Hall]], established on Canal Street, New Orleans, Louisiana. The first screen kiss takes place between [[May Irwin]] and [[John C. Rice|John Rice]] in ''[[The Kiss (1896 film)|The Kiss]]''. The first female film director, [[Alice Guy-Blaché]], presents ''[[La Fée aux Choux|The Cabbage Fairy]]''. Cinema reaches India by way of [[Auguste and Louis Lumière|The Lumière brothers]] ' Cinematography, unveiling six silent short films at the Watson Hotel in [[Bombay]], namely ''Entry of Cinematographe'', ''[[La Mer (Baignade en mer)]]'', ''[[L'Arrivée d'un Train en Gare de la Ciotat]]'', ''A Demolition'', ''Ladies & Soldiers on Wheels'' and ''Sortie de l'usine Lumière à Lyon''. The tour of the Lumière brothers covers also London and New York. * '''[[1897 in film|1897]]''' – [[Vitagraph]] is founded in New York. In England, the [[Prestwich Camera]] is patented. [[H. S. Bhatavdekar|Harischandra Sakharam Bhatvadekar]], alias Save Dada, imports a cine-camera from London at a price of 21 guineas<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.victorian-cinema.net/bhatvadekar|last=McKernan|first=Luke|title=Harishchandra Sakharam Bhatvadekar ('Save Dada')|website=Who's Who of Victorian Cinema|date=2018|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref> and films the first Indian [[documentary film]], a wrestling match in [[Hanging Gardens of Mumbai|Hanging Gardens]], [[Bombay]]. Daily screenings of films commence in [[Bombay]] by [[Clifton and Co.'s Meadows Street Photography Studio]]. 125 people die during a film screening at the Charity Bazaar in Paris after a curtain catches on fire from the ether used to fuel the projector lamp. * '''[[1898 in film|1898]]''' – Méliès starts producing under the brand Star Film and directs brief commercials. [[Hiralal Sen]] starts filming scenes of theatre productions at the [[Classic Theatre]] in [[Calcutta]]. * '''[[1899 in film|1899]]''' – The first long footage (over 100 meters), films with montage are made: ''[[L'Affaire Dreyfus (1899 film)|The Dreyfus Affair]]'' and the first film version of ''[[Cendrillon (1899 film)|Cinderella]]'' are both released by Méliès; the latter it is the first film to use a photographic dissolve (or fades). [[Georges Méliès]] also writes and directs ''[[Jeanne d'Arc (1899 film)|Jeanne d'Arc]]'', a film about Joan of Arc, which removes the viewer from spatial relations and institutionalized the use of the close-up.
==1900s== {{See also|1900s in film}} * '''[[1900 in film|1900]]''' – ''[[Sherlock Holmes Baffled]]'', ''[[The Enchanted Drawing]]'' * '''[[1901 in film|1901]]''' – ''[[Star Theatre (film)|Star Theatre]]'', ''[[Scrooge, or, Marley's Ghost]]'' * '''[[1902 in film|1902]]''' – ''[[A Trip to the Moon]]'' * '''[[1903 in film|1903]]''' – ''[[The Great Train Robbery (1903 film)|The Great Train Robbery]]'', ''[[Life of an American Fireman]]'' * '''[[1904 in film|1904]]''' – ''[[The Impossible Voyage]]''; [[Titanus]] is founded * '''[[1905 in film|1905]]''' – ''[[Adventures of Sherlock Holmes; or, Held for Ransom]]'' * '''[[1906 in film|1906]]''' – ''[[The Story of the Kelly Gang]]'', ''[[Humorous Phases of Funny Faces]]'', ''[[Dream of a Rarebit Fiend (1906 film)|Dream of a Rarebit Fiend]]''; [[Nordisk Film]] is founded * '''[[1907 in film|1907]]''' – ''[[Ben Hur (1907 film)|Ben Hur]]'', ''[[L'Enfant prodigue (film)|L'Enfant prodigue]]'' * '''[[1908 in film|1908]]''' – ''[[Fantasmagorie (1908 film)|Fantasmagorie]]'', ''[[The Taming of the Shrew (1908 film)|The Taming of the Shrew]]'', ''[[The Thieving Hand]]'', ''[[The Assassination of the Duke of Guise]]'', ''[[A Visit to the Seaside]]''; first use of [[Kinemacolor]]; [[Pathé News]] invents the [[newsreel]] * '''[[1909 in film|1909]]''' – ''[[The Country Doctor (film)|The Country Doctor]]'', ''[[A Corner in Wheat]]'', ''[[Les Misérables (1909 film)|Les Misérables]]'', ''[[Princess Nicotine; or, The Smoke Fairy]]''; [[35 mm film]] is accepted as international standard gauge
==1910s== {{See also|1910s in film}} * '''[[1910 in film|1910]]''' – ''[[In Old California (1910 film)|In Old California]]'', ''[[In the Border States]]'' * '''[[1911 in film|1911]]''' – ''[[L'Inferno (film)|L'Inferno]]'', ''[[Defence of Sevastopol]]'' * '''[[1912 in film|1912]]''' – ''[[Independenţa României]]'', ''[[The Musketeers of Pig Alley]]''; [[Universal Pictures]] and [[Paramount Pictures]], Hollywood's first two oldest studios, are founded * '''[[1913 in film|1913]]''' – ''[[The Bangville Police]]'', ''[[Barney Oldfield's Race for a Life]]'', ''[[Fantômas (1913 serial)|Fantômas]]'', ''[[Raja Harishchandra]]'' * '''[[1914 in film|1914]]''' – ''[[The Perils of Pauline (1914 serial)|The Perils of Pauline]]'', ''[[Judith of Bethulia]]'', ''[[Tillie's Punctured Romance (1914 film)|Tillie's Punctured Romance]]'', ''[[Cabiria]]'' * '''[[1915 in film|1915]]''' – ''[[The Birth of a Nation]]'', ''[[Les Vampires]]'', ''[[The Tramp (film)|The Tramp]]'', ''[[A Fool There Was (1915 film)|A Fool There Was]]'' * '''[[1916 in film|1916]]''' – ''[[Intolerance (film)|Intolerance]]'', ''[[The Queen of Spades (1916 film)|The Queen of Spades]]'', ''[[Gertie the Dinosaur]]'', ''[[20,000 Leagues Under the Sea (1916 film)|20,000 Leagues Under the Sea]]'', ''[[One A.M. (1916 film)|One A.M.]]''; invention of [[Technicolor]] * '''[[1917 in film|1917]]''' – ''[[Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm (1917 film)|Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm]]'', ''[[A Man There Was]]'', ''[[The Little Princess (1917 film)|The Little Princess]]'' * '''[[1918 in film|1918]]''' – ''[[Stella Maris (1918 film)|Stella Maris]]'', ''[[Mickey (1918 film)|Mickey]]'', ''[[Shifting Sands (film)|Shifting Sands]]'', ''[[A Dog's Life]]'', ''[[Shoulder Arms]]'' * '''[[1919 in film|1919]]''' – ''[[Blind Husbands]]'', ''[[Broken Blossoms]]'', ''[[True Heart Susie]]'', ''[[Male and Female]]'', ''[[Dalagang Bukid]]'', ''[[A Day's Pleasure]]''; [[United Artists]] is founded.
==1920s== {{See also|1920s in film}} * '''[[1920 in film|1920]]''' – ''[[Way Down East]]'', ''[[The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari]]'', ''[[The Golem: How He Came into the World]]'' * '''[[1921 in film|1921]]''' – ''[[The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse (film)|The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse]]'', ''[[The Phantom Carriage]]'', ''[[The Kid (1921 film)|The Kid]]'', ''[[Destiny (1921 film)|Destiny]]'', ''[[The Sheik (film)|The Sheik]]'' * '''[[1922 in film|1922]]''' – ''[[Nosferatu]]'', ''[[Nanook of the North]]'', ''[[Blood and Sand (1922 film)|Blood and Sand]]'', ''[[Foolish Wives]]'', ''[[Dr. Mabuse the Gambler]]'' * '''[[1923 in film|1923]]''' – ''[[Safety Last!]]'', ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]'', ''[[The Ten Commandments (1923 film)|The Ten Commandments]]'',; [[Warner Bros.
